questions.question:
The internal audit department wrote some scripts that are used for continuous auditing. The IT department
asked for copies of the scripts so that they can be used for setting up a continuous monitoring process on
key systems. Considering the ability of the information systems (IS) auditors to independently and objectively
audit the IT function, should sharing these scripts be permitted?

options.A:
Sharing the scripts is not permitted because it gives IT the ability to pre-audit systems and avoid an
accurate, comprehensive audit.
options.B:
Sharing the scripts is required because IT must have the ability to review all programs and software that
run on information systems regardless of audit independence.
options.C:
Sharing the scripts is permissible if IT recognizes that audits may be conducted in areas not covered in the
scripts.
options.D: Sharing the scripts is not permitted because the IS auditors who wrote the scripts would not be permitted to

justifications.A:
The ability of IT to continuously monitor and address any issues on IT systems does not affect the ability
of information systems (IS) audit to perform a comprehensive audit.
justifications.B:
Sharing the scripts may be required by policy for quality assurance and configuration management, but
that does not impair the ability to audit.
justifications.C:
IS audit may not be able to review the effectiveness of the scripts, but it can still audit all aspects of
the systems.
justifications.D:
An audit of an IS system encompasses more than just the controls covered in the scripts.

questions.question:
Which of the following is the BEST factor for determining the required extent of data collection during the
planning phase of an information systems (IS) compliance audit?

options.A: Complexity of the organization's operation
options.B: Findings and issues noted from the prior year
options.C: Purpose, objective and scope of the audit
options.D: Auditor's familiarity with the organization

justifications.A:
The complexity of the organization's operation is a factor in the planning of an audit but does not directly
affect the determination of how much data to collect. The extent of data collection is subject to the
intensity, scope and purpose of the audit.
justifications.B:
Prior findings and issues are factors in the planning of an audit but do not directly affect the determination
of how much data to collect. Data must be collected outside of areas of previous findings.
justifications.C:
The extent to which data will be collected during an information systems (IS) audit is related
directly to the purpose, objective and scope of the audit An audit with a narrow purpose and
limited objective and scope is most likely to result in less data collection than an audit with a wider
purpose and scope. Statistical analysis may also determine the extent of data collection, such as
sample size or means of data collection.
justifications.D:
An auditor's familiarity with the organization is a factor in the planning of an audit but does not directly
affect the determination of how much data to collect. The audit must be based on sufficient evidence of
the monitoring of controls and not unduly influenced by the auditor's familiarity with the organization.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is developing an audit plan for an environment that includes new
systems. Enterprise management wants the IS auditor to focus on recently implemented systems. How should
the IS auditor respond?

options.A: Audit the new systems as requested by management.
options.B: Audit systems not included in last year's scope.
options.C: Determine the highest-risk systems and plan accordingly.
options.D: Audit systems not in last year's scope and the new systems.

justifications.A:
Auditing the new systems does not reflect a risk-based approach. Although the systems can contain
sensitive data and may present risk of data loss or disclosure to the organization, without a risk
assessment, the decision to solely audit the newly implemented systems is not a risk-based decision.
justifications.B:
Auditing systems not included in the previous year's scope does not reflect a risk-based approach. In
addition, management may know about problems with the new systems and may intentionally try to steer
the audit away from that vulnerable area. Although, at first, the new system may seem to be the riskiest
area, an assessment must be conducted rather than relying on the judgment of the information systems
(IS) auditor or IT manager.
justifications.C:
The best action is to conduct a risk assessment and design the audit plan to cover the areas
of highest risk. ISACA IS Audit and Assurance Standard 1201 (Risk Assessment in Planning),
statement 1201.1: “The IT audit and assurance function shall use an appropriate risk assessment
approach (i.e., data-driven with both quantitative and qualitative factors) and supporting
methodology to develop the overall IT audit plan and to determine priorities for the effective
allocation of IT audit resources.”
justifications.D:
The creation of the audit plan should be performed in cooperation with management and based on risk.
The IS auditor should not arbitrarily decide on what needs to be audited.

questions.question:
What BEST describes the risk that information collected may contain a material error that may go undetected
during information systems (IS) auditing?

options.A: Inherent risk
options.B: Audit risk
options.C: Control risk
options.D: Detection risk

justifications.A:
Inherent risk is the risk level or exposure of the process/entity to be audited without considering the
controls that management has implemented.
justifications.B:
Audit risk is the probability that information or financial reports may contain material errors and
that the auditor may not detect an error that has occurred.
justifications.C:
Control risk is the risk that a material error exists that would not be prevented or detected on a timely
basis by the system of internal controls.
justifications.D:
Detection risk is the risk that material errors or misstatements that have occurred will not be detected by
an information systems (IS) auditor.

questions.question:
For which of the following controls would an information systems (IS) auditor look in an environment where
duties cannot be appropriately segregated?

options.A: Overlapping controls
options.B: Boundary controls
options.C: Access controls
options.D: Compensating controls

justifications.A:
Overlapping controls are two controls addressing the same control objective or exposure. Because
primary controls cannot be achieved when duties cannot or are not appropriately segregated, it is difficult
to install overlapping controls.
justifications.B:
Boundary controls establish the interface between the would-be user of a computer system and the
computer system itself and are individual-based, not role-based, controls.
justifications.C:
Access controls for resources are based on individuals and not on roles. For a lack of separation of duties,
the information systems (IS) auditor expects to find that a person has higher levels of access than are
ideal. The IS auditor wants to find compensating controls to address this risk.
justifications.D:
Compensating controls are internal controls that are intended to reduce the risk of an existing or
potential control weakness that may arise when duties cannot be appropriately segregated.

questions.question: Which of the following is a KEY benefit of a control self-assessment (CSA)?

options.A: Management ownership of the internal controls supporting business objectives is reinforced.
options.B: Audit expenses are reduced when the assessment results are an input to external audit work.
options.C: Fraud detection is improved because internal business staff* are engaged in testing controls.
options.D: Internal auditors can shift to a consultative approach by using the results of the assessment.

justifications.A:
The objective of control self-assessment (CSA) is to have business management become more aware
of the importance of internal control and their responsibility in terms of corporate governance.
justifications.B: Reducing audit expenses is not a key benefit of CSA.
justifications.C:
Improved fraud detection is important but not as important as control ownership. It is not a principal
objective of CSA.
justifications.D:
CSA may give more insights to internal auditors, allowing them to take a more consultative role;
however, this is an additional benefit, not the key benefit.
18 CIS A ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition

questions.question:
What is the PRIMARY requirement that a data mining and auditing software tool should meet? The software
tool should:

options.A: interfoce with various types of enterprise resource planning software and databases.
options.B: accurately capture data from the enterprise systems without causing excessive performance problems.
options.C: introduce audit hooks into the financial systems of the enterprise to support continuous auditing.
options.D: be customizable and support inclusion of custom programming to aid in investigative analysis.

justifications.A:
The product must interface with the types of systems used by the enterprise and provide meaningful data
for analysis.
justifications.B:
Although all the requirements that are listed as answer choices are desirable in a software tool
evaluated for auditing and data mining purposes, the most critical requirement is that the tool
works effectively on the systems of the enterprise being audited.
justifications.C:
The tool should probably work on more than just financial systems and does not necessarily require
implementation of audit hooks.
justifications.D:
The tool should be flexible but not necessarily customizable. It should have built-in analysis software
tools.

questions.question:
A long-term IT employee with a strong technical background and broad managerial experience has applied
for a vacant position in the information systems (IS) audit department. Determining whether to hire this
individual for this position should be PRIMARILY based on the individuaFs experience and:

options.A: length of service because this will help ensure technical competence.
options.B: age because training in audit techniques may be impractical.
options.C: IT knowledge because this will bring enhanced credibility to the audit function.
options.D: ability, as an IS auditor, to be independent of existing IT relationships.

justifications.A: Length of service does not ensure technical competency.
justifications.B:
Evaluating an individuafs qualifications based on the age of the individual is not a good criterion and is
illegal in many parts of the world.
justifications.C:
The fact that the employee has worked in IT for many years may not ensure credibility. The information
systems (IS) audit department's needs should be defined, and any candidate should be evaluated against
those requirements.
justifications.D:
Independence should be continually assessed by the auditor and management. This assessment
should consider such factors as changes in personal relationships, financial interests, and prior job
assignments and responsibilities.
19

questions.question:
For a retail business with a large volume of transactions, which of the following audit techniques is the
MOST appropriate for addressing emerging risk?

options.A: Use of computer-assisted audit techniques (CAATs)
options.B: Quarterly risk assessments
options.C: Sampling of transaction logs
options.D: Continuous auditing

justifications.A:
Using software tools such as computer-assisted audit techniques (CAATs) to analyze transaction data can
provide detailed analysis of trends and potential risk, but it is not as effective as continuous auditing,
because a time differential may exist between executing the software and analyzing the results.
justifications.B: Quarterly risk assessment may be a good technique but not as responsive as continuous auditing.
justifications.C:
The sampling of transaction logs is a valid audit technique; however, risk may exist that is not captured in
the transaction log, and the analysis may have a potential time lag.
justifications.D:
The implementation of continuous auditing enables a real-time feed of information to management
through automated reporting processes so that management may implement corrective actions
more quickly.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is reviewing access to an application to determine whether recently added
accounts were appropriately authorized. This is an example of:

options.A: variable sampling.
options.B: substantive testing.
options.C: compliance testing.
options.D: stop-or-go sampling.

justifications.A: Variable sampling is used to estimate numerical values, such as dollar values.
justifications.B:
Substantive testing substantiates the integrity of actual processing, such as balances on financial
statements. The development of substantive tests is often dependent on the outcome of compliance tests.
If compliance tests indicate that internal controls are adequate, then substantive tests can be minimized.
justifications.C:
Compliance testing determines whether controls are being applied in compliance with policy. This
includes tests to determine whether new accounts were appropriately authorized.
justifications.D:
Stop-or-go sampling allows a test to be stopped as early as possible and is not appropriate for checking
whether procedures have been followed.
20 C/SA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
The decisions and actions of an information systems (IS) auditor are MOST likely to affect which of the
following types of risk?

options.A: Inherent
options.B: Detection
options.C: Control
options.D: Business

justifications.A:
Inherent risk is the risk that a material error could occur, if there are no related internal controls to prevent
or detect the error. Inherent risk is not usually affected by an information systems (IS) auditor.
justifications.B:
Detection risk is directly affected by the IS auditor's selection of audit procedures and techniques.
Detection risk is the risk that a review will not detect or notice a material issue.
justifications.C:
Control risk is the risk that a material error exists that would not be prevented or detected on a timely
basis by the system of internal controls. Control risk can be mitigated by the actions of enterprise
management.
justifications.D:
Business risk is a probable situation with uncertain frequency and magnitude of loss (or gain). Business
risk is usually not directly affected by an IS auditor.

questions.question: Which of the following is the MOST critical step when planning an information systems (IS) audit?

options.A: Review findings from prior audits.
options.B: Obtain executive management approval of the audit plan
options.C: Review information security policies and procedures.
options.D: Perform a risk assessment.

justifications.A:
The findings of a previous audit are of interest to the auditor, but they are not the most critical step. The
most critical step involves finding the current issues or high-risk areas, not reviewing the resolution of
older issues. A review of historical audit findings can indicate that management is not resolving the items
or the recommendation was ineffective.
justifications.B:
Executive management is not required to approve the audit plan. It is typically approved by the audit
committee or board of directors. Management can recommend areas to audit.
justifications.C:
Reviewing information security policies and procedures is normally conducted during fieldwork, not
planning.
justifications.D:
Of all the steps listed, performing a risk assessment is the most critical. Risk assessment is required
by ISACA IS Audit and Assurance Standard 1201 (Risk Assessment in Planning), statement 1201.2:
“IT audit and assurance practitioners shall identify and assess risk relevant to the area under
review when planning individual engagements.,, In addition to the standards requirement, if a risk
assessment is not performed, then high-risk areas of the auditee systems or operations may not be
identified for evaluation.
21

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is reviewing a software application that is built on the principles of
service-oriented architecture. What is the INITIAL step?

options.A:
Understanding services and their allocation to business processes by reviewing the service repository
documentation
options.B:
Sampling the use of service security standards as represented by the Security Assertions Markup Language
(SAML)
options.C: Reviewing the service level agreements established for all system providers
options.D: Auditing the core service and its dependencies on other systems

justifications.A:
A service-oriented architecture relies on the principles of a distributed environment in which
services encapsulate business logic as a black box and might be deliberately combined to depict
real-world business processes. Before reviewing services in detail, it is essential for the information
systems (IS) auditor to comprehend the mapping of business processes to services.
justifications.B:
Sampling the use of service security standards as represented by Security Assertions Markup Language
(SAML) is an essential follow-up step to understanding services and their allocation to business but is not
the initial step.
justifications.C:
Reviewing the service level agreements is an essential follow-up step to understanding services and their
allocation to business but is not the initial step.
justifications.D:
Auditing the core service and its dependencies with others is most likely a part of the audit, but the IS
auditor must first gain an understanding of the business processes and how the systems support those
processes.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor conducting a review of software usage and licensing discovers that
numerous PCs contain unauthorized software. Which of the following actions should the IS auditor take?

options.A: Delete all copies of the unauthorized software.
options.B: Recommend an automated process to monitor for compliance with software licensing.
options.C: Report the use of the unauthorized software and the need to prevent recurrence.
options.D: Warn the end users about the risk of using illegal software.

justifications.A:
An information systems (IS) auditor should not assume the role of the enforcing officer and take on any
personal involvement in removing the unauthorized software.
justifications.B:
This would detect compliance with software licensing; however, an automated solution might not be the
best option in all cases.
C・ The use of unauthorized or illegal software should be prohibited by an organization. An IS auditor
must convince the user and management of the risk and the need to eliminate the risk. For example,
software piracy can result in exposure and severe fines.
justifications.C: No explanation available
justifications.D:
Auditors must report material findings to management for action. Informing the users of risk is not the
primary responsibility of the IS auditor.
22 C!SA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question: An audit charter should:

options.A: be dynamic and change to coincide with the changing nature of technology and the audit profession.
options.B:
clearly state the audit objectives and delegation of authority for the maintenance and review of internal
controls.
options.C: document the audit procedures designed to achieve the planned audit objectives.
options.D: outline the overall authority, scope and responsibilities of the audit function.

justifications.A:
The audit charter should not be subject to changes in technology and should not significantly change over
time. The charter should be approved at the highest level of management.
justifications.B:
An audit charter states the authority and reporting requirements for the audit but not the details of
maintenance of internal controls.
justifications.C:
An audit charter is not at a detailed level and, therefore, does not include specific audit objectives or
procedures.
justifications.D:
An audit charter should state management objectives for, and delegation of authority to,
information systems (IS) auditors.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor finds a small number of user access requests that were not authorized by
managers through the normal predefined workflow steps and escalation rules. The IS auditor should:

options.A: perform an additional analysis.
options.B: report the problem to the audit committee.
options.C: conduct a security risk assessment.
options.D: recommend that the owner of the identity management system fix the workflow issues.

justifications.A:
The information systems (IS) auditor needs to perform substantive testing and additional analysis
to determine why the approval and workflow processes are not working as intended. Before making
any recommendation, the IS auditor should gain a good understanding of the scope of the problem
and the factors that caused this incident. The IS auditor should identify whether the issue was
caused by managers not following procedures, a problem with the workflow of the automated
system or a combination of the two.
justifications.B: The IS auditor does not yet have enough information to report the problem.
justifications.C:
Changing the scope of the IS audit or conducting a security risk assessment requires more detailed
information about the processes and violations being reviewed.
justifications.D:
The IS auditor must first determine the root cause and impact of the findings and does not have enough
information to recommend fixing the workflow issues.
23

©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question: Which of the following sampling methods is MOST useful when testing for compliance?

options.A: Attribute sampling
options.B: Variable sampling
options.C: Stratified mean-per-unit sampling
options.D: Difference estimation sampling

justifications.A:
Attribute sampling is the primary sampling method used for compliance testing. Attribute
sampling is a sampling model that is used to estimate the rate of occurrence of a specific quality
(attribute) in a population and is used in compliance testing to confirm whether the quality exists.
For example, an attribute sample may check all transactions over a certain predefined dollar
amount for proper approvals.
justifications.B:
Variable sampling is based on the calculation of a mean from a sample extracted from the entire
population and using that to estimate the characteristics of the entire population. For example, a sample of
10 items shows an average price of US $10 per item. For the entire population of 1,000 items, the total
value is estimated to be US $10,
justifications.C: No explanation available
justifications.D: No explanation available

questions.question:
When testing program change requests for a remote system, an information systems (IS) auditor finds that
the number of changes available for sampling does not provide a reasonable level of assurance. What is the
MOST appropriate action for the IS auditor to take?

options.A: Develop an alternate testing procedure.
options.B: Report the finding to management.
options.C: Perform a walkthrough of the change management process.
options.D: Create additional sample data to test additional changes.

justifications.A:
If a sample-size objective cannot be met with the given data, the information systems (IS) auditor
cannot provide assurance regarding the testing objective. In this instance, the IS auditor should
develop (with audit management approval) an alternate testing procedure.
justifications.B: There is not enough evidence to report the finding as a deficiency.
justifications.C:
A walkthrough should not be initiated until an analysis is performed to confirm that this can provide the
required assurance.
justifications.D:
It is not appropriate for an IS auditor to create sample data for the purpose of the audit.
24 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manuall3th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
Which of the following situations can impair the independence of an information systems (IS) auditor? The IS
auditor:

options.A: implemented specific functionality during the development of an application.
options.B: designed an embedded audit module for auditing an application.
options.C: participated as a member of an application project team and did not have operational responsibilities.
options.D: provided consulting advice concerning application good practices.

justifications.A:
Independence may be impaired if an information systems (IS) auditor is, or was, actively involved
in the development, acquisition and implementation of the application system.
justifications.B: Designing an embedded audit module does not impair an IS auditor's independence.
justifications.C:
IS auditors should not audit work that they have done, but just participating as a member of the
application system project team does not impair an IS auditor's independence.
justifications.D: An IS auditor's independence is not impaired by providing advice on known good practices.

questions.question: The PRIMARY advantage of a continuous audit approach is that it:

options.A:
does not require an information systems (IS) auditor to collect evidence on system reliability while
processing is taking place.
options.B: allows the IS auditor to review and follow up on audit issues in a timely manner.
options.C:
places the responsibility for enforcement and monitoring of controls on the security department instead of
audit.
options.D: simplifies the extraction and correlation of data from multiple and complex systems.

justifications.A:
The continuous audit approach often requires an information systems (IS) auditor to collect evidence on
system reliability while processing is taking place.
justifications.B:
Continuous audit allows audit and response to audit issues in a timely manner because audit
findings are gathered in near real time.
justifications.C: Responsibility for enforcement and monitoring of controls is primarily the responsibility of management.
justifications.D: The use of continuous audit is not based on the complexity or number of systems being monitored.

questions.question: Which of the following impairs the independence of a quality assurance (QA) team?

options.A: Ensuring compliance with development methods
options.B: Checking the test assumptions
options.C: Correcting coding errors during the testing process
options.D: Checking the code to ensure proper documentation

justifications.A: Ensuring compliance with development methods is a valid quality assurance (QA) function.
justifications.B: Checking the test assumptions is a valid QA function.
justifications.C:
Correction of code should not be a responsibility of the QA team, because it does not ensure
separation of duties and impairs the team's independence.
justifications.D:
Checking the code to ensure proper documentation is a valid QA function.
25

questions.question: In planning an information systems (IS) audit, the MOST critical step is the identification of the:

options.A: areas of significant risk.
options.B: skill sets of the audit staff.
options.C: test steps in the audit.
options.D: time allotted for the audit.

justifications.A:
When designing a risk-based audit plan, it is important to identify the areas of highest risk to
determine the areas to be audited.
justifications.B:
The skill sets of the audit staff should have been considered before deciding and selecting the audit.
Where the skills are inadequate, the organization should consider using external resources.
justifications.C:
Test steps for the audit are not as critical during the audit planning process as identifying the areas of risk
that should be audited.
justifications.D:
The time allotted for an audit is determined during the planning process based on the areas to be audited
and is primarily based on the requirement for conducting an appropriate audit.

questions.question:
The MOST effective audit practice to determine whether controls accurately support the operational
effectiveness of transaction processing is:

options.A: control design testing.
options.B: substantive testing.
options.C: inspection of relevant documentation.
options.D: perform tests on risk prevention.

justifications.A:
Testing of control design assesses whether the control is structured to meet a specific control objective. It
does not help determine whether the control is operating effectively.
justifications.B:
Among other methods, such as document review or walkthrough, tests of controls are the most
effective procedures to assess whether controls accurately support operational effectiveness.
justifications.C:
Control documents may not always describe the actual process in an accurate manner. Therefore, auditors
relying on document review have limited assurance that the control is operating as intended.
justifications.D:
Performing tests on risk prevention is considered compliance testing. This type of testing is used to
determine whether policies are adhered to.
26 Cl SA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
The extent to which data will be collected during an information systems (IS) audit should be determined
based on the:

options.A: availability of critical and required information.
options.B: auditor's familiarity with the circumstances.
options.C: auditee's ability to find relevant evidence.
options.D: purpose and scope of the audit being done.

justifications.A:
The extent to which data will be collected during an information systems (IS) audit should be based on
the scope, purpose and requirements of the audit and not be constrained by the ease of obtaining the
information or by the IS auditor's familiarity with the area being audited.
justifications.B:
An IS auditor must be objective and thorough and not subject to audit risk through preconceived expected
results based on familiarity with the area being audited.
justifications.C:
Collecting all the required evidence is a required element of an IS audit, and the scope of the audit should
not be limited by the auditee's ability to find relevant evidence. If evidence is not readily available, the
auditor must ensure that other forms of audit are considered to ensure compliance in the area that is
subject to audit.
justifications.D:
The extent to which data will be collected during an IS audit should be related directly to the scope
and purpose of the audit. An IS audit with a narrow purpose and scope, or just a high-level review,
will most likely require less data collection than an audit with a wider purpose and scope.

questions.question: While planning an information systems (IS) audit, an assessment of risk should be made to provide:

options.A: reasonable assurance that the audit will cover material items.
options.B: definite assurance that material items will be covered during the audit work.
options.C: reasonable assurance that all items will be covered by the audit.
options.D: sufficient assurance that all items will be covered during the audit work.

justifications.A:
ISACA Information Systems (IS) Audit and Assurance Performance Guideline 2201 (Risk
Assessment in Planning) states that the applied risk assessment approach should help with the
prioritization and scheduling process of the IS audit and assurance work. The risk assessment
should support the selection process of areas and items of audit interest and the decision process to
design and conduct particular IS audit engagements.
justifications.B: Definite assurance that material items will be covered during the audit work is an impractical proposition.
justifications.C:
Reasonable assurance that all items will be covered during the audit work is not the correct answer,
because primarily material items need to be covered, not all items.
justifications.D:
Sufficient assurance that all items will be covered is not as important as ensuring that the audit will cover
all material items.
27

©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
The MOST appropriate action for an information systems (IS) auditor to take when shared user accounts are
discovered is to:

options.A: inform the audit committee of the potential issue.
options.B: review audit logs for the IDs in question.
options.C: document the finding and explain the risk of using shared IDs.
options.D: request that the IDs be removed from the system.

justifications.A:
It is not appropriate for an information systems (IS) auditor to report findings to the audit committee
before conducting a more detailed review and presenting them to management for a response.
justifications.B: Review of audit logs would not be useful because shared IDs do not provide for individual accountability.
justifications.C:
An IS auditor's role is to detect and document findings and control deflciencies. Part of the audit
report is to explain the reasoning behind the findings. The use of shared IDs is not recommended
because it does not allow for accountability of transactions. An IS auditor defers to management to
decide how to respond to the findings presented.
justifications.D: It is not the role of an IS auditor to request the removal of IDs from the system.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is conducting a compliance test to determine whether controls support
management policies and procedures. The test will assist the IS auditor to determine:

options.A: that the control is operating efficiently.
options.B: that the control is operating as designed.
options.C: the integrity of data controls.
options.D: the reasonableness of financial reporting controls.

justifications.A:
It is important that controls operate efficiently, but, in this case, the intent is to ensure that the controls
support management policies and procedures. Therefore, the important issue is whether the controls are
operating correctly and thereby meeting the control objective.
justifications.B:
Compliance tests can be used to test the existence and effectiveness of a defined process.
Understanding the objective of a compliance test is important Information systems (IS) auditors
want reasonable assurance that the controls on which they are relying are effective. An effective
control is one that meets management expectations and objectives.
justifications.C: Substantive tests, not compliance tests, are associated with data integrity.
justifications.D:
Determining the reasonableness of financial reporting controls is a very narrow answer because it is
limited to financial reporting. It meets the objective of determining whether the controls are reasonable
but does not ensure that the control is working correctly and thereby supporting management expectations
and objectives.

questions.question:
The vice president of human resources has requested an information systems (IS) audit to identify payroll
overpayments for the previous year. Which is the BEST audit technique to use in this situation?

options.A: Generate sample test data
options.B: Generalized audit software
options.C: Integrated test facility
options.D: Embedded audit module

justifications.A:
Test data tests for the existence of controls that might prevent overpayments, but it does not detect
specific, previous miscalculations.
justifications.B:
Generalized audit software features include mathematical computations, stratification, statistical
analysis, sequence checking, duplicate checking and recomputations. An information systems (IS)
auditor, using generalized audit software, can design appropriate tests to recompute the payroll,
thereby determining whether overpayments were made and to whom.
justifications.C:
An integrated test facility helps to identify a problem as it occurs but does not detect errors for a previous
period.
justifications.D:
An embedded audit module can enable the IS auditor to evaluate a process and gather audit evidence, but
it does not detect errors for a previous period.

questions.question:
During a security audit of IT processes, an information systems (IS) auditor finds that documented security
procedures do not exist. The IS auditor should:

options.A: create the procedures document based on the practices.
options.B: issue an opinion of the current state and end the audit.
options.C: conduct compliance testing on available data.
options.D: identify and evaluate existing practices.

justifications.A:
Information systems (IS) auditors should not prepare documentation, because the process may not be
compliant with management objectives and doing so can jeopardize their independence.
justifications.B:
Ending the audit and issuing an opinion does not address identification of potential risk. The auditor
should evaluate the practices in place. The recommendation may still be for the organization to develop
written procedures. Terminating the audit may prevent achieving one of the basic audit objectives一
identification of potential risk.
Because there are no documented procedures, there is no basis against which to test compliance.
One of the main objectives of an audit is to identify potential risk; therefore, the most proactive
approach is to identify and evaluate the existing security practices being followed by the
organization and submit the findings and risk to management, with recommendations to document
the current controls or enforce the documented procedures.
29
CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.
justifications.C: No explanation available
justifications.D: No explanation available

questions.question:
During a risk analysis, an information systems (IS) auditor identifies threats and potential impacts. Next, the
IS auditor should:

options.A: ensure that the risk assessment is aligned to managemenfs risk assessment process.
options.B: identify information assets and the underlying systems.
options.C: disclose the threats and impacts to management.
options.D: identify and evaluate the existing controls.

justifications.A:
An audit risk assessment is conducted for purposes that are different from managemenfs risk assessment
process purposes.
justifications.B:
It is impossible to determine impact without first identifying the assets affected; therefore, this must
already have been completed.
justifications.C:
Upon completion of a risk assessment, an information systems (IS) auditor should describe and discuss
with management the threats and potential impacts on the assets, and recommendations for addressing the
risk. However, this action cannot be done until the controls are identified and the likelihood of the threat
is calculated.
justifications.D:
It is important for an IS auditor to identify and evaluate the existence and effectiveness of existing
and planned controls so that the risk level can be calculated after the potential threats and possible
impacts are identified.

questions.question:
Which of the following would normally be the MOST reliable evidence for an information systems (IS)
auditor?

options.A: A confirmation letter received from a third party verifying an account balance
options.B: Assurance from line management that an application is working as designed
options.C: Trend data obtained from Internet sources
options.D: Ratio analysis developed by the IS auditor from reports supplied by line management

justifications.A:
Evidence obtained from independent third parties is almost always considered to be more reliable
than assurance provided by local management
justifications.B:
Because management is not objective and may not understand the risk and control environment, and
it is only providing evidence that the application is working correctly (not the controls), management
assurance is not an acceptable level of trust for audit evidence.
justifications.C: Data collected from the Internet is not always trustworthy or independently validated.
justifications.D:
Ratio analysis can identify trends and deviations from a baseline but is not reliable evidence.
30 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
When evaluating the collective effect of preventive, detective and corrective controls within a process, an
information systems (IS) auditor should be aware of which of the following?

options.A: The point at which controls are exercised as data flow through the system.
options.B: Only preventive and detective controls are relevant.
options.C: Corrective controls are regarded as compensating.
options.D: Classification allows an IS auditor to determine the controls that are missing.

justifications.A:
An information systems (IS) auditor should focus on when controls are exercised as data flow
through a computer system.
justifications.B: Corrective controls may also be relevant because they allow an error or problem to be corrected.
justifications.C:
Corrective controls remove or reduce the effects of errors or irregularities and are not exclusively
regarded as compensating controls.
justifications.D: The existence and function of controls are important but not the classification.

questions.question: Which audit technique provides the BEST evidence of the separation of duties in an IT department?

options.A: Discussion with management
options.B: Review of the organization chart
options.C: Observation and interviews
options.D: Testing of user access rights

justifications.A:
Management may not be aware of the detailed functions of each employee in the IT department and
whether the controls are being followed. Therefore, discussion with management provides only limited
information regarding separation of duties.
justifications.B:
An organization chart does not provide details of the functions of the employees or whether the controls
are working correctly.
justifications.C:
Based on the observations and interviews, the information systems (IS) auditor can evaluate the
separation of duties. By observing the IT staff performing their tasks, an IS auditor can identify
whether they are performing any incompatible operations. By interviewing the IT staff, the auditor
can get an overview of the tasks performed.
justifications.D:
Testing of user rights provides information about the rights users have within the information systems but
does not provide complete information about the functions they perform. Observation is a better option
because user rights can be changed between audits.
31

questions.question:
After reviewing the disaster recovery planning process of an organization, an information systems (IS) auditor
requests a meeting with organization management to discuss the findings, Which of the following BEST
describes the main goal of this meeting?

options.A: Obtain management approval of the corrective action plan.
options.B: Confirm factual accuracy of the findings.
options.C: Assist management in the implementation of corrective actions.
options.D: Prioritize the resolution of the items.

justifications.A:
Management approval of the corrective action plan is not required. Management can elect to implement
another corrective action plan to address the risk.
justifications.B:
The goal of the meeting is to confirm the factual accuracy of the audit findings and present an
opportunity for management to agree on or respond to recommendations for corrective action.
justifications.C:
Implementation of corrective actions should be done after the factual accuracy of findings is established,
but the work of implementing corrective action is not typically assigned to the information systems (IS)
auditor, because this impairs the auditor's independence.
justifications.D:
Rating the audit findings provides guidance to management for allocating resources to the high-risk items
first.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor should ensure that review of online electronic funds transfer
reconciliation procedures includes:

options.A: vouching.
options.B: authorizations.
options.C: corrections.
options.D: tracing.

justifications.A: Vouching is usually performed during the funds transfer, not during the reconciliation effort.
justifications.B:
In online processing, authorizations are normally done automatically by the system, not during the
reconciliation.
justifications.C:
Correction entries should be reviewed during a reconciliation; however, they are normally done by an
individual other than the person entrusted to do reconciliations and are not as important as tracing.
justifications.D:
Tracing is a transaction reconciliation effort that involves following the transaction from the
original source to its final destination. In electronic funds transfer transactions, the direction on
tracing may start from the customer-printed copy of the receipt, proceed to checking the system
audit trails and logs, and end with checking the master Hie records for daily transactions.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is carrying out a system configuration review. Which of the following is
the BEST evidence in support of the current system configuration settings?

options.A: System configuration values that are imported to a spreadsheet by the system administrator
options.B:
Standard report with configuration values that are retrieved from the system by the information systems
(IS) auditor
options.C: Dated screenshot of the system configuration settings that are made available by the system administrator
options.D: Annual review of approved system configuration values by the business owner

justifications.A:
Evidence that is not system-generated information can be modified before it is presented to an
information systems (IS) auditor. Therefore, it may not be as reliable as evidence that is obtained by
the IS auditor. For example, a system administrator can change the settings or modify the graphic image
before taking a screenshot.
justifications.B:
Evidence that is obtained directly from the source by an IS auditor is more reliable than
information that is provided by a system administrator or a business owner because the IS auditor
does not have a vested interest in the outcome of the audit.
justifications.C:
The rules may be modified by the administrator prior to taking the screenshot; therefore, this is not the
best evidence.
justifications.D: The annual review provided by a business owner may not reflect cunent information.

questions.question:
The purpose of a checksum on an amount field in an electronic data interchange communication of financial
transactions is to ensure:

options.A: integrity.
options.B: authenticity.
options.C: authorization.
options.D: nonrepudiation.

justifications.A:
A checksum that is calculated on an amount field and included in the electronic data interchange
communication can be used to identify unauthorized modifications.
justifications.B: Authenticity cannot be established by a checksum alone and needs other controls.
justifications.C: Authorization cannot be established by a checksum alone and needs other controls.
justifications.D:
Nonrepudiation can be ensured by using digital signatures.
33

questions.question:
Which of the following forms of evidence does an information systems (IS) auditor consider the MOST
reliable?

options.A: An oral statement from the auditee
options.B: The results of a test that is performed by an external information systems (IS) auditor
options.C: An internally generated computer accounting report
options.D: A confirmation letter that is received from an outside source

justifications.A:
An oral statement from the auditee is audit evidence but not as reliable as the results of a test that is
performed by an external information systems (IS) auditor.
justifications.B:
An independent test that is performed by an IS auditor should always be considered a more reliable
source of evidence than a confirmation letter from a third party, because the letter is the result of
an analysis of the process and may not be based on authoritative audit techniques. An audit should
consist of a combination of inspection, observation and inquiry by an IS auditor as determined by
risk. This provides a standard methodology and reasonable assurance that the controls and test
results are accurate.
justifications.C:
An internally generated computer accounting report is audit evidence but is not as reliable as the results of
a test performed by an external IS auditor.
justifications.D:
An independent test performed by an IS auditor should always be considered a more reliable source of
evidence than a confirmation letter from a third party, because a letter is subjective and may not have been
generated as a part of an authoritative audit or conform to audit standards.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor who has discovered unauthorized transactions during a review of
electronic data interchange (EDI) transactions is likely to recommend improving the:

options.A: EDI trading partner agreements.
options.B: physical controls for terminals.
options.C: authentication techniques for sending and receiving messages.
options.D: program change control procedures.

justifications.A:
Electronic data interchange trading partner agreements minimize exposure to legal issues but do not
resolve the problem of unauthorized transactions.
justifications.B:
Physical control is important and may provide protection from unauthorized people accessing the system
but does not provide protection from unauthorized transactions by authorized users.
justifications.C:
Authentication techniques for sending and receiving messages play a key role in minimizing
exposure to unauthorized transactions.
justifications.D:
Change control procedures do not resolve the issue of unauthorized transactions.
34 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA, All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is validating a control that involves a review of system-generated
exception reports. Which of the following is the BEST evidence of the effectiveness of the control?

options.A: Walk-through with the reviewer of the operation of the control
options.B: System-generated exception reports forthe review period with the reviewer's sign-off
options.C:
A sample system-generated exception report for the review period, with follow-up action items noted by
the reviewer
options.D: Managemenfs confirmation of the effectiveness of the control forthe review period

justifications.A:
A walk-through highlights how a control is designed to work, but it seldom highlights the effectiveness of
the control, or exceptions or constraints in the process.
justifications.B:
Reviewer sign-off does not demonstrate the effectiveness of the control if the reviewer does not note
follow-up actions for the exceptions identified.
justifications.C:
A sample of a system-generated report with evidence that the reviewer followed up on the
exceptions represents the best possible evidence of the effective operation of the control, because
there is documented evidence that the reviewer reviewed the exception report and took actions
based on the exception report.
justifications.D:
Managemenfs confirmation of effectiveness of the control suffers from lack of independence一
management might be biased toward the effectiveness of the controls put in place.

questions.question:
An enterprise has recently upgraded its purchase system to incorporate electronic data interchange (EDI)
transmissions. Which of the following controls should be implemented in the EDI interface to provide
efficient data mapping?

options.A: Key verification
options.B: One-for-one checking
options.C: Manual recalculations
options.D: Functional acknowledgments

justifications.A: Key verification is used for encryption and protection of data but not for data mapping.
justifications.B: One-for-one checking validates that transactions are accurate and complete but does not map data.
justifications.C: Manual recalculations are used to verify that the processing is correct but do not map data.
justifications.D:
Acting as an audit trail for electronic data interchange transactions, functional acknowledgments
are one of the main controls used in data mapping.
35

questions.question:
Which of the following sampling methods is the MOST effective to determine whether purchase orders issued
to vendors have been authorized as per the authorization matrix?

options.A: Variable sampling
options.B: Stratified mean per unit
options.C: Attribute sampling
options.D: Unstratified mean per unit

justifications.A:
Variable sampling is the method used for substantive testing, which involves testing transactions for
quantitative aspects such as monetary values.
justifications.B: Stratified mean per unit is used in variable sampling.
justifications.C:
Attribute sampling is the method used for compliance testing. In this scenario, the operation of
a control is being evaluated, and therefore, the attribute of whether each purchase order was
correctly authorized would be used to determine compliance with the control.
justifications.D: Unstratified mean per unit is used in variable sampling.

questions.question: The BEST method of confirming the accuracy of a system tax calculation is by:

options.A: review and analysis of the source code of the calculation programs.
options.B: recreating program logic using generalized audit software to calculate monthly totals.
options.C: preparing simulated transactions for processing and comparing the results to predetermined results.
options.D: automatic flowcharting and analysis of the source code of the calculation programs.

justifications.A:
A review of source code is not an effective method of ensuring that the calculation is being computed
correctly.
justifications.B:
Recreating program logic may lead to errors, and monthly totals are not accurate enough to ensure correct
computations.
justifications.C:
Preparing simulated transactions for processing and comparing the results to predetermined results
is the best method for confirming the accuracy of a tax calculation.
justifications.D:
Flowcharting and analysis of source code are not effective methods to address the accuracy of individual
tax calculations.
36 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question: An information systems (IS) auditor performing a review of application controls evaluates the:

options.A: efficiency of the application in meeting the business processes.
options.B: impact of any exposures discovered.
options.C: business processes served by the application.
options.D: application optimization.

justifications.A:
The information systems (IS) auditor is reviewing the effectiveness of the controls, not the suitability of
the application to meet business needs.
justifications.B:
An application control review involves the evaluation of the application automated controls and an
assessment of any exposures resulting from the control weaknesses.
justifications.C:
The other choices may be objectives of an application audit but are not part of an audit restricted to a
review of the application controls.
justifications.D:
One area to be reviewed may be the efficiency and optimization of the application, but this is not the area
being reviewed in this audit.

questions.question:
Corrective action has been taken by an auditee immediately after the identification of a reportable finding. The
information systems (IS) auditor should:

options.A:
include the finding in the final report because the IS auditor is responsible for an accurate report of all
findings.
options.B: not include the finding in the final report because management resolved the item.
options.C:
not include the finding in the final report because corrective action can be verified by the IS auditor during
the audit.
options.D: include the finding in the closing meeting for discussion purposes only.

justifications.A:
Including the flnding in the final report is a generally accepted audit practice. If an action is taken
after the audit started and before it ended, the audit report should identify the finding and describe
the corrective action taken. An audit report should reflect the situation, as it existed at the start of
the audit All corrective actions taken by the auditee should be reported in writing.
justifications.B:
The audit report should contain all relevant findings and the response from management even if the
finding has been resolved. This means that subsequent audits may test for the continued resolution of the
control.
justifications.C:
The audit report should contain the finding so that it is documented and the removal of the control
subsequent to the audit is noticed.
justifications.D:
The audit report should contain the finding and resolution, and this can be mentioned in the final meeting.
The audit report should list all relevant findings and the response from management.
37

©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
The internal information systems (IS) audit team is auditing controls over sales returns and is concerned about
fraud. Which of the following sampling methods will BEST assist the IS auditors?

options.A: Stop-or-go
options.B: Classical variable
options.C: Discovery
options.D: Probability-proportional-to-size

justifications.A:
Stop-or-go is a sampling method that helps limit the size of a sample and allows the test to be stopped at
the earliest possible moment.
justifications.B:
Classical variable sampling is associated with dollar amounts and has a sample based on a representative
sample of the population but is not focused on fraud.
justifications.C:
Discovery sampling is used when an information systems (IS) auditor is trying to determine
whether a type of event has occurred. Therefore, it is suited to assess the risk of fraud and to
identify whether a single occurrence has taken place.
justifications.D:
Probability-proportional-to-size sampling is typically associated with cluster sampling when there are
groups within a sample. The question does not indicate that an IS auditor is searching for a threshold of
fraud.

questions.question:
When developing a risk-based audit strategy, an information systems (IS) auditor should conduct a risk
assessment to ensure that:

options.A: controls needed to mitigate risk are in place.
options.B: vulnerabilities and threats are identified.
options.C: audit risk is considered.
options.D: a gap analysis is appropriate.

justifications.A:
Determination of whether appropriate controls that are required to mitigate risk are in place is a result of
an audit.
justifications.B:
While developing a risk-based audit strategy, it is critical that the risk and vulnerabilities are
understood. They determine the areas to be audited and the extent of coverage.
justifications.C:
Audit risk is an inherent aspect of auditing, directly related to the audit process and not relevant to the risk
analysis of the environment to be audited.
justifications.D:
A gap analysis is normally done to compare the actual state to an expected or desirable state.
38 C/SA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13比 Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
During an exit interview, in cases where there is disagreement regarding the impact of a finding, an
information systems (IS) auditor should:

options.A: ask the auditee to sign a release form accepting full legal responsibility.
options.B: elaborate on the significance of the finding and the risk of not correcting it.
options.C: report the disagreement to the audit committee for resolution.
options.D: accept the auditee position because they are the process owners.

justifications.A:
Management is always responsible and liable for risk. The role of the information systems (IS) auditor is
to inform management of the findings and associated risk discovered in an audit.
justifications.B:
If the auditee disagrees with the impact of a finding, it is important for an IS auditor to elaborate
and clarify the risk and exposures because the auditee may not fully appreciate the magnitude of
the exposure. The goal should be to enlighten the auditee or uncover new information of which an
IS auditor may not have been aware. Anything that appears to threaten the auditee lessens effective
communications and sets up an adversarial relationship, but an IS auditor should not automatically
agree just because the auditee expresses an alternate point of view.
justifications.C:
The audit report contains the finding from the IS auditor and the response from management. It is the
responsibility of management to accept risk or mitigate it appropriately. The role of the auditor is to
inform management clearly and thoroughly so that the best decision can be made.
justifications.D:
The IS auditor must be professional, competent and independent. They must not just accept an
explanation or argument from management, unless the process used to generate the finding was flawed.

questions.question:
To ensure that audit resources deliver the best value to the organization, the FIRST step in an audit project is
to:

options.A: schedule the audits and monitor the time spent on each audit.
options.B: train the information systems (IS) audit staff on current technology used in the organization.
options.C: develop the audit plan based on a detailed risk assessment.
options.D: monitor progress of audits and initiate cost control measures.

justifications.A:
Monitoring the audits and the time spent on audits is not effective if the wrong areas are being audited. It
is most important to develop a risk-based audit plan to ensure effective use of audit resources.
justifications.B:
The information systems (IS) auditor may have specialties, or the audit team may rely on outside experts
to conduct very specialized audits. It is not necessary for each IS auditor to be trained on all new
technology.
justifications.C:
Although monitoring the time and audit programs, and adequate training improve the IS audit
staffs productivity (efficiency and performance), ensuring that the resources and efforts being
dedicated to audit are focused on higher-risk areas delivers value to the organization.
justifications.D:
Monitoring audits and initiating cost controls does not ensure the effective use of audit resources.
39
CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
Which of the following should be the FIRST action of an information systems (IS) auditor during a dispute
with a department manager over audit findings?

options.A: Retest the control to validate the finding.
options.B: Engage a third party to validate the finding.
options.C: Include the finding in the report with the department manager's comments.
options.D: Revalidate the supporting evidence for the finding.

justifications.A: Retesting the control normally occurs after the evidence has been revalidated.
justifications.B:
Although there are cases where a third party may be needed to perform specialized audit procedures,
an information systems (IS) auditor should first revalidate the supporting evidence to determine whether
there is a need to engage a third party.
justifications.C:
Before putting a disputed finding or management response in the audit report, the IS auditor should take
care to review the evidence that is used in the finding to ensure audit accuracy.
justifications.D:
Conclusions drawn by an IS auditor should be adequately supported by evidence, and any
compensating controls or corrections that are pointed out by a department manager should be
taken into consideration. Therefore, the first step is to revalidate the evidence for the finding. If,
after revalidating and retesting, there are unsettled disagreements, those issues should be included
in the report.

questions.question: An information systems (IS) auditor should use statistical sampling when:

options.A: the probability of error must be objectively quantified.
options.B: the auditor wants to avoid sampling risk.
options.C: generalized audit software is unavailable.
options.D: the tolerable error rate cannot be determined.

justifications.A:
Given an expected error rate and confidence level, statistical sampling is an objective method of
sampling that helps an information systems (IS) auditor determine the sample size and quantify the
probability of error (confidence coefficient).
justifications.B:
Sampling risk is the risk of a sample not being representative of the population. This risk exists for
judgment and statistical samples.
justifications.C: Statistical sampling can use generalized audit software, but it is not required.
justifications.D:
The tolerable error rate must be predetermined for both judgment and statistical sampling.
40 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
What is the BEST action for an information systems (IS) auditor to take when an outsourced monitoring
process for remote access is inadequate and management disagrees because intrusion detection system (IDS)
and firewall controls are in place?

options.A: Revise the finding in the audit report per managemenfs feedback.
options.B: Retract the finding because the IDS controls are in place.
options.C: Retract the finding because the firewall rules are monitored.
options.D: Document the identified finding in the audit report.

justifications.A:
The information systems (IS) auditor may include the management response in the report, but that will not
affect the requirement to report the finding.
justifications.B:
The finding remains valid and the management response is documented; however, the audit may indicate
a need to review the validity of the management response.
justifications.C:
The finding remains valid and the management response is documented; however, the audit may indicate
a need to review the validity of the management response.
justifications.D:
IS auditor independence dictates that the additional information provided by the auditee is taken
into consideration. Normally, an IS auditor does not automatically retract or revise the finding.

questions.question:
An organization uses a bank to process its weekly payroll. Time sheets and payroll adjustment forms (e.g.,
hourly rate changes and terminations) are completed and delivered to the bank, which prepares the checks and
reports for distribution. To BEST ensure payroll data accuracy:

options.A: payroll reports should be compared to input forms.
options.B: gross payroll should be recalculated manually.
options.C: checks should be compared to input forms.
options.D: checks should be reconciled with output reports.

justifications.A:
The best way to confirm data accuracy, when input is provided by the organization and output
is generated by the bank, is to verify the data input (input forms) with the results of the payroll
reports.
justifications.B:
Recalculating gross payroll manually only verifies whether the processing is correct and not the data
accuracy of inputs.
justifications.C:
Comparing checks to input forms is not feasible because checks contain the processed information and
input forms contain the input data.
justifications.D:
Reconciling checks with output reports only confirms that checks were issued as stated on output reports.
41
CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
Which of the following represents the GREATEST potential risk in an electronic data interchange (EDI)
environment?

options.A: Lack of transaction authorizations
options.B: Loss or duplication of EDI transmissions
options.C: Transmission delay
options.D: Deletion or manipulation of transactions prior to, or after, establishment of application controls

justifications.A:
Because the interaction between parties is electronic, there is no inherent authentication occurring;
therefore, lack of transaction authorization is the greatest risk.
justifications.B:
Loss or duplication of electronic data interchange transmissions is an example of risk, but because all
transactions should be logged, the impact is not as great as that of unauthorized transactions.
justifications.C:
Transmission delays may terminate the process or hold the line until the normal time for processing has
elapsed; however, there will be no loss of data.
justifications.D:
Deletion or manipulation of transactions prior to, or after, establishment of application controls is an
example of risk. Logging detects any alteration to the data, and the impact is not as great as that of
unauthorized transactions.

questions.question: During the planning stage of an information systems (IS) audit, the PRIMARY goal of an IS auditor is to:

options.A: address audit objectives.
options.B: collect sufficient evidence.
options.C: specify appropriate tests
options.D: minimize audit resources

justifications.A: ISACA Information Systems (IS) Audit and Assurance Standards require that an IS auditor plan the audit work to address the audit objectives. The activities described in the other options are all undertaken to address audit objectives and, thus, are secondary.
justifications.B: The IS auditor does not collect evidence in the planning stage of an audit
justifications.C: Specifying appropriate tests is not the primary goal of audit planning
justifications.D: Effective use of audit resources is a goal of audit planning, not minimizing audit resources

questions.question:
When selecting audit procedures, an information systems (IS) auditor should use professional judgment to
ensure that:

options.A: sufficient evidence will be collected.
options.B: significant deficiencies will be corrected within a reasonable period.
options.C: all material weaknesses will be identified.
options.D: audit costs will be kept at a minimum level.

justifications.A:
Procedures are processes that an information systems (IS) auditor may follow in an audit
engagement. In determining the appropriateness of any specific procedure, an IS auditor should
use professional judgment that is appropriate to the specific circumstances. Professional judgment
involves a subjective and often qualitative evaluation of conditions arising during an audit.
Judgment addresses a grey area where binary (yes/no) decisions are not appropriate, and the
IS auditor's past experience plays a key role in making a judgment. The IS auditor should
use judgment in assessing the sufficiency of evidence to be collected. ISACA guidelines provide
information on how to meet the standards when performing IS audit work.
justifications.B:
The correction of deficiencies is the responsibility of management and is not a part of the audit procedure
selection process.
justifications.C:
Identifying material weaknesses is the result of appropriate competence, experience and thoroughness
in planning and executing the audit, and not of professional judgment. Professional judgment is not a
primary input to the financial aspects of the audit. Audit procedures and use of professional judgment
cannot ensure that all deficiencies/weaknesses will be identified and conected.
justifications.D:
Professional judgment ensures that audit resources and costs are used wisely, but this is not the primary
objective of the auditor when selecting audit procedures.

questions.question: A substantive test to verify that tape library inventory records are accurate is:

options.A: determining whether bar code readers are installed.
options.B: determining whether the movement of tapes is authorized.
options.C: conducting a physical count of the tape inventory.
options.D: checking whether receipts and issues of tapes are accurately recorded.

justifications.A: Determining whether bar code readers are installed is a compliance test.
justifications.B: Determining whether the movement of tapes is authorized is a compliance test.
justifications.C:
A substantive test includes gathering evidence to evaluate the integrity (i.e., the completeness,
accuracy and validity) of individual transactions, data or other information. Conducting a physical
count of the tape inventory is a substantive test.
justifications.D:
Checking whether receipts and issues of tapes are accurately recorded is a compliance test.

questions.question:
An appropriate control for ensuring the authenticity of orders received in an electronic data interchange
system application is to:

options.A: acknowledge receipt of electronic orders with a confirmation message.
options.B: perform reasonableness checks on quantities ordered before filling orders.
options.C: verify the identity of senders and determine if orders correspond to contract terms.
options.D: encrypt electronic orders.

justifications.A:
Acknowledging the receipt of electronic orders with a confirming message is good practice but will not
authenticate orders from customers.
justifications.B:
Performing reasonableness checks on quantities ordered before placing orders is a control for ensuring the
correctness of the orders, not the authenticity of its customer orders.
justifications.C:
An electronic data interchange system is subject not only to the usual risk exposures of computer
systems but also to those arising from the potential ineffectiveness of controls on the part of the
trading partner and the third-party service provider, making authentication of users and messages
a major security concern.
justifications.D:
Encrypting sensitive messages is an appropriate step but does not prove authenticity of messages
received.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor finds that the answers received during an interview with a payroll clerk
do not support job descriptions and documented procedures. Under these circumstances, the IS auditor should:

options.A: conclude that the controls are inadequate.
options.B: expand the scope to include substantive testing.
options.C: place greater reliance on previous audits.
options.D: suspend the audit.

justifications.A:
Based solely on the interview with the payroll clerk, the information systems (IS) auditor will not be able
to collect evidence to determine the adequacy of existing controls.
justifications.B:
If the answers provided to an IS auditor's questions are not confirmed by documented procedures
or job descriptions, the IS auditor should expand the scope of testing the controls and include
additional substantive tests.
justifications.C:
Placing greater reliance on previous audits is an inappropriate action because it provides no current
knowledge of the adequacy of the existing controls.
justifications.D:
Suspending the audit is an inappropriate action because it provides no current knowledge of the adequacy
of the existing controls.

questions.question:
An external information systems (IS) auditor issues an audit report pointing out the lack of firewall protection
features at the perimeter network gateway and recommending a specific vendor product to address this
vulnerability. The IS auditor has failed to exercise:

options.A: professional independence.
options.B: organizational independence.
options.C: technical competence.
options.D: professional competence.

justifications.A:
When an information systems (IS) auditor recommends a specific vendor, the auditor's professional
independence is compromised.
justifications.B:
Organizational independence has no relevance to the content of an audit report and should be considered

justifications.C: Technical competence is not relevant to the requirement of independence.
justifications.D: Professional competence is not relevant to the requirement of independence.

questions.question:
The PRIMARY reason an information systems (IS) auditor performs a functional walk-through during the
preliminary phase of an audit assignment is to:

options.A: understand the business process.
options.B: comply with auditing standards.
options.C: identify control weakness.
options.D: develop the risk assessment.

justifications.A:
Understanding the business process is the first step that an information systems (IS) auditor needs
to perform.
justifications.B:
ISACA IS Audit and Assurance Standards encourage adoption of the audit procedures/processes required
to assist the IS auditor in performing IS audits more effectively. However, standards do not require an IS
auditor to perform a process walk-through at the commencement of an audit engagement.
justifications.C:
Identifying control weaknesses is not the primary reason for the walk-through and typically occurs at a
later stage in the audit.
justifications.D:
The main reason is to understand the business process. The risk assessment is developed after the business
process is understood.

questions.question:
In the process of evaluating program change controls, an information systems (IS) auditor uses source code
comparison software to:

options.A: examine source program changes without information from IS personnel.
options.B: detect a source program change made between acquiring a copy of the source and the comparison run.
options.C: confirm that the control copy is the current version of the production program.
options.D: ensure that all changes made in the current source copy are tested.

justifications.A:
When an information systems (IS) auditor uses a source code comparison to examine source
program changes without information from IS personnel, the IS auditor has an objective,
independent and relatively complete assurance of program changes because the source code
comparison identifies the changes.
justifications.B:
The changes detected by the source code comparison are between two versions of the software. This does
not detect changes made since the acquisition of the copy of the software.
justifications.C:
This is a function of library management, not source code comparison. An IS auditor gains this assurance
separately.
justifications.D:
Source code comparison detects all changes between an original and a changed program; however, the
comparison will not ensure that the changes have been adequately tested.

questions.question: The PRIMARY purpose for meeting with auditees prior to formally closing a review is to:

options.A: confirm that the auditors did not overlook any important issues.
options.B: gain agreement on the findings.
options.C: receive feedback on the adequacy of the audit procedures.
options.D: test the structure of the final presentation.

justifications.A:
The closing meeting identifies any misunderstandings or errors in the audit but does not identify any
important issues overlooked in the audit.
justifications.B:
The primary purpose for meeting with auditees prior to formally closing a review is to gain
agreement on the findings and responses from management
justifications.C:
The closing meeting may obtain comments from management on the conduct of the audit but is not
intended to be a formal review of the adequacy of the audit procedures.
justifications.D:
The structure of an audit report and the presentation follows accepted standards and practices. The closing
meeting may indicate errors in the audit or presentation but is not intended to test the structure of the
presentation.
46 CIS A ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
