questions.question:
Which of the following audit techniques BEST helps an information systems (IS) auditor to determine
whether unauthorized program changes have been made since the last authorized program update?

options.A: Test data run
options.B: Code review
options.C: Automated code comparison
options.D: Review of code migration procedures

justifications.A:
Test data runs permit the auditor to verify the processing of preselected transactions but provide no
evidence about unauthorized changes or unexercised portions of a program.
justifications.B:
Code review is the process of reading program source code listings to determine whether the code follows
coding standards or contains potential errors or inefficient statements. A code review can be used as a
means of code comparison, but it is inefficient and unlikely to detect any changes in the code, especially
in a large program.
justifications.C:
An automated code comparison is the process of comparing two versions of the same program
to determine whether the two correspond. It is an efficient technique because it is an automated
procedure.
justifications.D: The review of code migration procedures does not detect unauthorized program changes.

questions.question:
When preparing an audit report, the information systems (IS) auditor should ensure that the results are
supported by:

options.A: statements from IS management.
options.B: work papers of other auditors.
options.C: an organizational control self-assessment.
options.D: sufficient and appropriate audit evidence.

justifications.A:
Statements from information systems (IS) management may be included in the audit analysis but these
statements alone are not considered a sufficient basis for issuing a report.
justifications.B:
Work papers from other auditors may be used to substantiate and validate a finding but should not be used
without the additional evidence of the work papers from the IS auditor who is preparing the report.
justifications.C:
The results of a control self-assessment may assist the IS auditor in determining risk and compliance but
on its own is not enough to support the audit report.
justifications.D:
ISACA IS Audit and Assurance Reporting Standards require that the IS auditor has sufficient
and appropriate audit evidence to support the reported results. Statements from IS management
provide a basis for obtaining concurrence on matters that cannot be verified with empirical
evidence. The report should be based on evidence that is collected during the review even
though the IS auditor may have access to the work papers of other auditors. The results of an
organizational control self-assessment can supplement the audit findings.
47

questions.question: The final decision to include a material finding in an audit report should be made by the:

justifications.C:

questions.question:
While reviewing sensitive electronic work papers, the information systems (IS) auditor notices that they were
not encrypted. This could compromise the:

options.A: audit trail of the versioning of the work papers.
options.B: approval of the audit phases.
options.C: access rights to the work papers.
options.D: confidentiality of the work papers.

justifications.A:
Audit trails do not, by themselves, affect confidentiality, but are part of the reason for requiring
encryption.
justifications.B:
Audit phase approvals do not, by themselves, affect the confidentiality of the work papers, but are part of
the reason for requiring encryption.
justifications.C:
Access to the work papers should be limited by need to know; however, alack of encryption breaches the

justifications.D: Encryption provides confidentiality for electronic work papers.

questions.question:
The MOST important reason for an information systems (IS) auditor to obtain sufficient and appropriate audit
evidence is to:

options.A: comply with regulatory requirements.
options.B: provide a basis for drawing reasonable conclusions.
options.C: ensure complete audit coverage.
options.D: perform the audit according to the defined scope.

justifications.A:
Complying with regulatory requirements is relevant to an audit but is not the most important reason why
sufficient and relevant evidence is required.
justifications.B:
The scope of an information systems (IS) audit is defined by its objectives. This involves identifying
control weaknesses relevant to the scope of the audit Obtaining sufficient and appropriate evidence
assists the auditor in not only identifying control weaknesses but also documenting and validating
them.
justifications.C:
Ensuring coverage is relevant to conducting an IS audit but is not the most important reason why
sufficient and relevant evidence is required. The reason for obtaining evidence is to ensure that the audit
conclusions are factual and accurate.
justifications.D:
The execution of an audit to meet its defined scope is relevant to an audit but is not the reason why
sufficient and relevant evidence is required.

questions.question:
After initial investigation, an information systems (IS) auditor has reasons to believe that fraud may be
present. The IS auditor should:

options.A: expand activities to determine whether an investigation is warranted.
options.B: report the matter to the audit committee.
options.C: report the possibility of fraud to management.
options.D: consult with external legal counsel to determine the course of action to be taken.

justifications.A:
An information systems (IS) auditor's responsibilities for detecting fraud include evaluating fraud
indicators, and deciding whether any additional action is necessary or whether an investigation
should be recommended.
justifications.B:
The IS auditor should notify the appropriate authorities within the organization only if it has determined
that the indicators of fraud are sufficient to recommend an investigation.
justifications.C:
The IS auditor should report the possibility of fraud to top management only after there is sufficient
evidence to launch an investigation. This may be affected by whether management may be involved in the
fraud.
justifications.D: Normally, the IS auditor does not have authority to consult with external legal counsel.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor notes that failed login attempts to a core financial system are
automatically logged and the logs are retained for a year by the organization. This logging is:

options.A: an effective preventive control.
options.B: a valid detective control.
options.C: not an adequate control.
options.D: a conective control.

justifications.A: Generation of an activity log is not a preventive control because it cannot prevent inappropriate access.
justifications.B:
Generation of an activity log is not a detective control because it does not help in detecting inappropriate
access unless it is reviewed by appropriate personnel.
justifications.C:
Generation of an activity log is not a control by itself It is the review of such a log that makes the
activity a control (i.e., generation plus review equals control).
justifications.D:
Generation of an activity log is not a corrective control because it does not correct the effect of
inappropriate access.

questions.question: An organization's information systems (IS) audit charter should specify the:

options.A: plans for IS audit engagements.
options.B: objectives and scope of IS audit engagements.
options.C: detailed training plan for the IS audit staff.
options.D: role of the IS audit function.

justifications.A: Planning is the responsibility of audit management.
justifications.B:
The objectives and scope of each information systems (IS) audit should be agreed on in an engagement
letter. The charter specifies the objectives and scope of the audit function but not of individual
engagements.
justifications.C: A training plan that is based on the audit plan should be developed by audit management.
justifications.D:
An IS audit charter establishes the role of the information systems audit function. The charter
should describe the overall authority, scope and responsibilities of the audit function. The charter
should be approved by the highest level of management and, if available, by the audit committee.

questions.question:
Which of the following should an information systems (IS) auditor use to detect duplicate invoice records
within an invoice master file?

options.A: Attribute sampling
options.B: Computer-assisted audit techniques (CAATs)
options.C: Compliance testing
options.D: Integrated test facility

justifications.A:
Attribute sampling aids in identifying records meeting specific conditions but does not compare one
record to another to identify duplicates. To detect duplicate invoice records, the information systems (IS)
auditor should check all items that meet the criteria and not just a sample of the items.
justifications.B:
Computer-assisted audit techniques (CAATs) enable the IS auditor to review the entire invoice file
to look for those items that meet the selection criteria.
justifications.C:
Compliance testing determines whether control procedures are adhered to. Using CAATs is the better
option because it is most likely more efficient to search for duplicates.
justifications.D:
An integrated test facility allows the IS auditor to test transactions through the production system but does
not compare records to identify duplicates.

questions.question: When developing a risk management program, what is the FIRST activity to be performed?

options.A: Threat assessment
options.B: Classification of data
options.C: Inventory of assets
options.D: Criticality analysis

justifications.A:
The assets need to be identified first. A listing of the threats that can affect the assets is a later step in the
process.
justifications.B:
Data classification is required for defining access controls and in criticality analysis, but the assets
(including data) need be identified before doing classification.
justifications.C:
Identification of the assets to be protected is the first step in the development of a risk management
program.
justifications.D: Criticality analysis is a later step in the process after the assets have been identified.

questions.question:
When evaluating the controls of an electronic data interchange (EDI) application, an information systems (IS)
auditor should PRIMARILY be concerned with the risk of:

options.A: excessive transaction turnaround time.
options.B: application interface failure.
options.C: improper transaction authorization.
options.D: nonvalidated batch totals.

justifications.A: An excessive turnaround time is an inconvenience, but not a serious risk.
justifications.B:
The failure of the application interface is a risk, but not the most serious issue. Usually such a problem is
temporary and easily fixed.
justifications.C:
Foremost among the risk associated with electronic data interchange (EDI) is improper transaction
authorization. Because the interaction with the parties is electronic, there is no inherent
authentication. Improper authentication poses a serious risk of financial loss.
justifications.D:
The integrity of EDI transactions is important, but not as significant as the risk of unauthorized
transactions.

questions.question:
Which of the following would be MOST useful for an information systems (IS) auditor for accessing and
analyzing digital data to collect relevant audit evidence from diverse software environments?

options.A: Structured Query Language (SQL)
options.B: Application software reports
options.C: Data analytics controls
options.D: Computer-assisted auditing techniques (CAATs)

justifications.A:
Structured Query Language (SQL) provides options for auditors to query specific tables of a database
according to audit objectives. However, skills are required to query specific databases, and a user must be
able to understand the record structure to access the data.
justifications.B:
Reports from application software may be useful, but they are not as beneficial as computer-assisted
auditing techniques (CAATs).
justifications.C:
Data analytics controls might be a good technique to use for control testing, but they are not as
comprehensive as CAATs.
justifications.D:
CAATs are tools used for accessing data in an electronic form from diverse software environments,
record formats, etc. CAATs serve as useful tools for collecting and evaluating audit evidence
according to audit objectives and can create efficiencies for collecting this evidence.

questions.question:
Which of the following sampling methods is the MOST appropriate for testing automated invoice
authorization controls to ensure that exceptions are not made for specific users?

options.A: Variable sampling
options.B: Judgmental sampling
options.C: Stratified random sampling
options.D: Systematic sampling

justifications.A:
Variable sampling is used for substantive testing to determine the monetary or volumetric impact of
characteristics of a population. This is not the most appropriate method in this case.
justifications.B:
In judgmental sampling, professionals place a bias on the sample (e.g., all sampling units over a certain
value, all for a specific type of exception or all negatives). A judgmental sample is not statistically
based, and results should not be extrapolated over the population because the sample is unlikely to be
representative of the population.
justifications.C:
Stratification is the process of dividing a population into subpopulations with similar characteristics
explicitly defined, so that each sampling unit can belong to only one stratum. This method of
sampling ensures that all sampling units in each subgroup have a known, nonzero chance of
selection. It is the most appropriate method in this case.
justifications.D:
Systematic sampling involves selecting sampling units using a fixed interval between selections with the
first interval having a random start. This is not the most appropriate method in this case.
53
CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor who was involved in designing an organization's business continuity plan
(BCP) has been assigned to audit the plan. The IS auditor should:

options.A: decline the assignment.
options.B: inform management of the possible conflict of interest after completing the audit assignment.
options.C: inform the BCP team of the possible conflict of interest prior to beginning the assignment.
options.D: confirm the possibility of conflict of interest to audit management prior to starting the assignment.

justifications.A:
Declining the assignment can be acceptable only after obtaining management approval or it is
appropriately disclosed to management, audit management and other stakeholders.
justifications.B: Approval should be obtained prior to commencement and not after the completion of the assignment.
justifications.C:
Informing the business continuity plan (BCP) team of the possible conflict of interest prior to starting the
assignment is not the conect answer because the BCP team does not have the authority to decide on this
issue.
justifications.D:
A possible conflict of interest, likely to affect the information systems (IS) auditor's independence,
should be brought to the attention of management prior to starting the assignment.

questions.question: The PRIMARY purpose of an IT forensic audit is:

options.A: to participate in investigations related to corporate fraud.
options.B: to enable the systematic collection and analysis of evidence after a system irregularity.
options.C: To assess the correctness of an organization's financial statements.
options.D: to preserve evidence of criminal activity.

justifications.A: Forensic audits are not limited to corporate fraud.
justifications.B:
The systematic collection and analysis of evidence after a system irregularity best describes a
forensic audit. The evidence collected can then be analyzed and used in judicial proceedings.
justifications.C:
Assessing the correctness of an organization's financial statements is not the primary purpose of most
forensic audits.
justifications.D:
Forensics is the investigation of evidence related to a crime or misbehavior. Preserving evidence is the
forensic process, but not the primary purpose.
54 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor reviews one day of logs for a remotely managed server and finds one
case where logging failed, and the backup restarts cannot be confirmed. What should the IS auditor do?

options.A: Issue an audit finding.
options.B: Seek an explanation from IS management.
options.C: Review the classifications of data held on the server.
options.D: Expand the sample of logs reviewed.

justifications.A:
At this stage, it is too preliminary to issue an audit finding. Seeking an explanation from management
is advisable, but it is better to gather additional evidence to properly evaluate the seriousness of the
situation.
justifications.B:
Without gathering more information on the incident and the frequency of the incident, it is difficult to
obtain a meaningful explanation from management.
justifications.C:
A backup failure, which has not been established at this point, is serious if it involves critical data.
However, the issue is not the importance of the data on the server, where a problem has been detected, but
whether a systematic control failure that impacts other servers exists.
justifications.D:
IS Audit and Assurance Standards require that an IS auditor gather sufficient and appropriate
audit evidence. The IS auditor found a potential problem and now needs to determine whether this
is an isolated incident or a systematic control failure.

questions.question:
Ina small organization, the function of release manager and application programmer are performed by the
same employee. What is the BEST compensating control in this scenario?

options.A: Hiring additional staff to provide separation of duties
options.B: Preventing the release manager from making program modifications
options.C: Logging of changes to development libraries
options.D: Verifying that only approved program changes are implemented

justifications.A:
Establishing separation of duties is not a compensating control; it is a preventive control. In a small
organization, it may not be feasible to hire new staff, which is why a compensating control may be
necessary.
justifications.B:
Because the release manager is performing dual roles, preventing the release manager from making
program modifications is not feasible, and, in a small organization, separation of duties may not be
possible.
justifications.C: Logging changes to development libraries does not detect changes to production libraries.
justifications.D:
Compensating controls are used to mitigate risk when proper controls are not feasible or practical.
In a small organization, it may not be feasible to hire new staff, which is why a compensating
control may be necessary. Verifying program changes has roughly the same effect as intended by
full separation of duties.
55
CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question: Which of the following is the FIRST step in an IT risk assessment for a risk-based audit?

options.A: Identify all IT systems and controls that are relevant to audit objectives.
options.B: List all controls from the audit program to select ones matching with audit objectives.
options.C: Review the results of a risk self assessment.
options.D: Understand the business, its operating model and key processes.

justifications.A:
Understanding the business environment comes first; this is followed by understanding the IT
environment.
justifications.B:
Listing controls and matching them to audit objectives is not the first step of risk assessment. This step
follows understanding the business environment and the IT systems.
justifications.C: A risk self assessment is optional and applicable for some types of audit engagements.
justifications.D:
Risk-based auditing must be based on an understanding of the business, operating model and
environment This is the first step in an IT risk assessment for a risk-based audit

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor discovers that devices connected to the network are not included in a
network diagram that had been used to develop the scope of the audit. The chief information officer explains
that the diagram is being updated and awaiting final approval. The IS auditor should FIRST:

options.A: expand the scope of the IS audit to include the devices that are not on the network diagram.
options.B: evaluate the impact of the undocumented devices on the audit scope.
options.C: note a control deficiency because the network diagram has not been approved.
options.D: plan follow-up audits of the undocumented devices.

justifications.A:
It is important that the information systems (IS) auditor does not immediately assume that everything on
the network diagram provides information about the risk affecting a network/system. There is a process in
place for documenting and updating the network diagram.
justifications.B:
In a risk-based approach to an IS audit, the scope is determined by the impact that the devices will
have on the audit. If the undocumented devices do not impact the audit scope, then they may be
excluded from the current audit engagement. The information provided on a network diagram can
vary depending on what is being illustrated—for example, the network layer and cross connections.
justifications.C:
In this case, there is simply a mismatch in timing between the completion of the approval process and
when the IS audit began. There is no control deficiency to be reported.
justifications.D:
Planning for follow-up audits of the undocumented devices is contingent on the risk that the
undocumented devices have on the ability of the entity to meet the audit scope.
56 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13比 Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is testing employee access to a large financial system and selects a
sample from the current employee list provided by the auditee. Which of the following evidence is the MOST
reliable to support the testing?

options.A: A spreadsheet provided by the system administrator
options.B: Human resources access documents signed by employees, managers
options.C: A list of accounts with access levels generated by the system
options.D: Observations performed onsite in the presence of a system administrator

justifications.A:
A spreadsheet supplied by the system administrator may not be complete or may be inaccurate.
Documentary evidence should be collected to support the auditee's spreadsheet.
justifications.B:
The human resources access documents signed by managers are good evidence; however, they are not as
objective as the system-generated access list, because access may have changed, or the documents may
have been incorrect when they were signed.
justifications.C:
The access list generated by the system is the most reliable because it is the most objective evidence
to perforin a comparison against the samples selected. The evidence is objective because it was
generated by the system rather than by an individual.
justifications.D:
The observations are good evidence to understand the internal control structure; however, observations
are not efficient for many users. Observations are not objective enough for substantive tests.

questions.question:
During a compliance audit of a small bank, the information systems (IS) auditor notes that the IT and
accounting functions are being performed by the same user of the financial system. Which of the following
reviews that are conducted by the user's supervisor represents the BEST compensating control?

options.A: Audit trails that show the date and time of the transaction
options.B: A daily report with the total numbers and dollar amounts of each transaction
options.C: User account administration
options.D: Computer log files that show individual transactions

justifications.A:
An audit trail of only the date and time of the transaction is not sufficient to compensate forthe risk of
multiple functions being performed by the same individual.
justifications.B: Review of the summary financial reports does not compensate for the separation of duties issue.
justifications.C:
Supervisor review of user account administration can be a good control; however, it may not detect
inappropriate activities where a person fills multiple roles.
justifications.D:
Computer logs record the activities of individuals during their access to a computer system or data
file and record any abnormal activities, such as the modification or deletion of financial data.
57

questions.question:
A system developer transfers to the audit department to serve as an IT auditor. When production systems are
to be reviewed by this employee, which of the following will become the MOST significant concern?

options.A: The work may be construed as a self-audit.
options.B: Audit points may largely shift to technical aspects.
options.C: The employee may not have sufficient control assessment skills.
options.D: The employee's knowledge of business risk may be limited.

justifications.A:
Because the employee had been a developei; it is recommended that the audit coverage should
exclude the systems developed by this employee to avoid any conflicts of interests.
justifications.B:
Because the employee has a technical background, it is possible that the audit findings tend to focus on
technical matters. However, this is normally corrected in the review process before it is carried out in
production.
justifications.C:
Because auditing is a new role for this employee, they may not have adequate control assessment skills.
However, this can be addressed by on-the-job training and is not as big of a concern as a potential conflict
of interest.
justifications.D:
Because this employee was previously employed in the organization's IT department, it is possible to
build upon the employee's current understanding of the business to address any gaps in knowledge.

questions.question: Which ofthe following BEST describes the objective of an information systems (IS) auditor discussing the audit findings with the auditee?

options.A: Communicate results to the auditee
options.B: Develop timelines for the implementation ofsuggested recommendations
options.C: Confirm the findings and propose a course of corrective action
options.D: Identify compensating controls to the identified risk.

justifications.A: Based on this discussion, the information systems (IS) auditor will finalize the report and present the report to relevant levels ofsenior management after the findings are confirmed. This discussion should, however, also address a timetable for remediation ofthe audit findings.
justifications.B: This discussion informs management ofthe findings ofthe audit. Based on these discussions, management may agree to develop an implementation plan for the suggested recommendations, along with the timelines.
justifications.C: Before communicating the results of an audit to senior management, the IS auditor should discuss the findings with the auditee. The goal ofthis discussion is to confirm the accuracy ofthe findings and to propose a course of corrective action.
justifications.D: At the draft report stage, the IS auditor may recommend various controls to mitigate the risk, but the purpose ofthe meeting is to validate the findings ofthe audit with management.

questions.question:
Which of the following responsibilities is MOST likely to compromise the independence of an information
systems (IS) auditor when reviewing the risk management process?

options.A: Participating in the design of the risk management framework
options.B: Advising on different implementation techniques
options.C: Facilitating risk awareness training
options.D: Performing a due diligence review of the risk management processes

justifications.A:
Participating in the design of the risk management framework involves designing controls,
which compromises the independence of the information systems (IS) auditor to audit the risk
management process.
justifications.B:
Advising on different implementation techniques does not compromise the IS auditor's independence
because the IS auditor will not be involved in the decision-making process.
justifications.C:
Facilitating awareness training does not hamper the IS auditor's independence because the auditor will not
be involved in the decision-making process.
justifications.D: Due diligence reviews are a type of audit generally related to mergers and acquisitions.

questions.question:
Which of the following is the GREATEST concern if audit objectives are not established during the initial
phase of an audit program?

options.A: Key stakeholders are incorrectly identified.
options.B: Control costs will exceed the planned budget.
options.C: Important business risk may be overlooked.
options.D: Previously audited areas may be inadvertently included.

justifications.A:
In certain cases, it may be difficult to discuss findings when incorrect stakeholders are identified, thus
delaying the communication of audit findings. However, this is not as concerning as important business
risk not being included in audit scope.
justifications.B:
Many factors determine the cost of controls. Therefore, it is difficult to state that only audit objectives will
determine the control cost. However, this is not as important if the key risk is not identified.
justifications.C:
Without an audit scope, the appropriate risk assessment has not been performed, and therefore, the
auditor might not audit those areas of highest risk for the organization.
justifications.D:
Auditing previously audited areas is not an efficient use of resources; however, this is not as big of a
concern as key risk not being identified.
59

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor wants to analyze audit trails on critical servers to discover potential
anomalies in user or system behavior. Which of the following is the MOST suitable for performing that task?

options.A: Computer-aided software engineering tools
options.B: Embedded data collection tools
options.C: Trend/variance detection tools
options.D: Heuristic scanning tools

justifications.A: Computer-aided software engineering tools are used to assist in software development.
justifications.B:
Embedded (audit) data collection software, such as systems control audit review file or systems audit
review file, is used to provide sampling and production statistics, but not to conduct an audit log analysis.
justifications.C:
Trend/variance detection tools look for anomalies in user or system behavior, such as invoices with
increasing invoice numbers.
justifications.D: Heuristic scanning tools are a type of virus scanning used to indicate possible infected traffic.

questions.question:
While performing an audit of an accounting application's internal data integrity controls, an information
systems (IS) auditor identifies a major control deficiency in the change management software supporting the
accounting application. The MOST appropriate action for the IS auditor to take is to:

options.A:
continue to test the accounting application controls and inform the IT manager about the control deficiency
and recommend possible solutions.
options.B: complete the audit and not report the control deficiency because it is not part of the audit scope.
options.C: continue to test the accounting application controls and include the deficiency in the final report.
options.D: cease all audit activity until the control deficiency is resolved.

justifications.A:
The information systems (IS) auditor should not assume that the IT manager will follow through on a
verbal notification to resolve the change management control deficiency, and it is inappropriate to offer
consulting services on issues discovered during an audit.
justifications.B:
Although not technically within the audit scope, it is the responsibility of the IS auditor to report findings
discovered during an audit that can have a material impact on the effectiveness of controls.
justifications.C:
It is the responsibility of the IS auditor to report on findings that can have a material impact on the
effectiveness of controls—whether they are within the scope of the audit
justifications.D:
It is not the role of the IS auditor to demand that IT work be completed before performing or completing
an audit.
60 C/SA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13比 Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
Which of the following will MOST successfully identify overlapping key controls in business application
systems?

options.A: Reviewing system functionalities that are attached to complex business processes
options.B: Submitting test transactions through an integrated test facility
options.C: Replacing manual monitoring with an automated auditing solution
options.D: Testing controls to validate that they are effective

justifications.A:
In general, highly complex business processes may have more key controls than business areas with
less complexity; however, finding, with certainty, unnecessary controls in complex areas is not always
possible. If a well-thought-out key control structure was established from the beginning, finding any
overlap in key controls will not be possible.
justifications.B:
An integrated test facility is an audit technique to test the accuracy of the processes in the application
system. This technique may find control flaws in the application system, but it would be difficult for it to
find the overlap in key controls.
justifications.C:
As part of the effort to realize continuous audit management, there are cases for introducing
an automated monitoring and auditing solution. All key controls need to be clearly aligned for
systematic implementation; thus, analysts can discover unnecessary or overlapping key controls in
existing systems.
justifications.D:
By testing controls to validate whether they are effective, the information systems (IS) auditor can
identify whether there are overlapping controls; however, the process of implementing an automated
auditing solution better identifies overlapping controls.

questions.question: When performing a risk analysis, the information systems (IS) auditor should FIRST:

options.A: review the data classification program.
options.B: Identify the organization's information assets.
options.C: identify the inherent risk of the system.
options.D: perform a cost-benefit analysis for controls.

justifications.A:
After the business objectives and the underlying systems are identified, the greatest degree of risk
management effort should be focused on those assets containing data considered most sensitive to the
organization. The data classification program assists the information systems (IS) auditor in identifying
these assets.
justifications.B:
The first step of the risk assessment process is to identify the systems and processes that support the
business objectives because risk to those processes impacts the achievement of business goals.
justifications.C:
Inherent risk is exposure without considering the actions that management has taken or might take. The
purpose of a risk assessment is to identify vulnerabilities so that mitigating controls can be established.
However, one must first understand the business and its supporting systems to best identify systems
requiring the most risk assessment effort.
justifications.D:
Designing and implementing controls to mitigate inherent risk of critical systems can only be performed
after the above steps have been taken.
61

questions.question: After identifying the findings, the information systems (IS) auditor should FIRST:

options.A: gain agreement on the findings.
options.B: determine mitigation measures for the findings.
options.C: inform senior management of the findings.
options.D: obtain remediation deadlines to close the findings.

justifications.A:
If findings are not agreed upon and confirmed by both parties, then there may be an issue
during sign-off on the final audit report or while discussing findings with management. When
an agreement is obtained with the auditee, it implies that the finding is understood and a clear plan
of action can be determined.
justifications.B:
Although the auditor may recommend mitigation measures, the organization ultimately decides and
implements the mitigation strategies as a function of risk management.
justifications.C:
Before senior management is informed, it is imperative that the auditor informs the auditee and gains
agreement on the audit findings to correctly communicate the risk.
justifications.D:
Obtaining remediation deadlines to close the findings is not the first step in communicating the audit
findings.

questions.question:
A PRIMARY benefit derived for an organization employing control self-assessment (CSA) techniques is that
it:

options.A: can identify high-risk areas that might need a detailed review later.
options.B: allows information systems (IS) auditors to independently assess risk.
options.C: can be used as a replacement for traditional audits.
options.D: allows management to relinquish responsibility for control.

justifications.A:
Control self-assessment (CSA) is predicated on the review of high-risk areas that either need
immediate attention or may require a more thorough review laten
justifications.B:
CSA requires the involvement of information systems (IS) auditors and line management. The internal
audit function shifts some of the control monitoring responsibilities to the functional areas.
justifications.C:
CSA is not a replacement for traditional audits. CSA is not intended to replace audifs responsibilities, but
to enhance them.
justifications.D:
CSA does not allow management to relinquish its responsibility for control.
62 C/SA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
Which of the following is the FIRST step performed prior to creating a risk ranking for the annual internal
information systems (IS) audit plan?

options.A: Prioritize the identified risk.
options.B: Define the audit universe.
options.C: Identify the critical controls.
options.D: Determine the testing approach.

justifications.A:
After the audit universe is defined, the information systems (IS) auditor can prioritize risk based on its
overall impact on different operational areas of the organization covered under the audit universe.
justifications.B:
In a risk-based audit approach, the IS auditor identifies risk to the organization based on the
nature of the business. To plan an annual audit cycle, the types of risk must be ranked. To rank the
types of risk, the auditor must first define the audit universe by considering the IT strategic plan,
organizational structure and authorization matrix.
justifications.C:
The controls that help in mitigating high-risk areas are generally critical controls and their effectiveness
provides assurance on mitigation of risk. However, this cannot be done unless the types of risk are ranked.
justifications.D: The testing approach is based on the risk ranking.

questions.question:
Which of the following is MOST likely to be considered a conflict of interest for an information systems (IS)
auditor who is reviewing a cybersecurity implementation?

options.A: Delivering cybersecurity awareness training
options.B: Designing the cybersecurity controls
options.C: Advising on the cybersecurity framework
options.D: Conducting the vulnerability assessment

justifications.A:
Delivering cybersecurity awareness training is typically an operational responsibility, but it is not nearly
as strong a conflict of interest as the auditor designing controls and then reviewing them.
justifications.B:
If an auditor designs the controls, a conflict of interest arises in the neutrality of the auditor to
address deficiencies during an audit. This is in violation of the ISACA Code of Ethics.
justifications.C:
Part of the role of an information systems (IS) auditor can be to advise on a cybersecurity framework,
provided that such advice does not rise to the level of designing specific controls that the auditor would
later review.
justifications.D:
Conducting a vulnerability assessment can be the responsibility of the IS auditor and does not present a
conflict of interest.
63
CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manuall3th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor identifies a business process to be audited. The IS auditor should NEXT
identify the:

options.A: most valuable information assets.
options.B: IS audit resources to be deployed.
options.C: auditee personnel to be interviewed.
options.D: control objectives and activities.

justifications.A:
All assets need to be identified, not just information assets. To determine the key information assets to
be audited, the information systems (IS) auditor should first determine which control objectives and key
control activities should be validated. Only information assets that are related to the control objectives and
key control activities are relevant for scoping the audit.
justifications.B:
Only after determining which controls and related relevant information assets are to be validated can the
IS auditor decide on the key IS audit resources (with the relevant skill sets) that should be deployed for
the audit.
justifications.C:
Only after determining the key control activities to be validated can the IS auditor identify the relevant
process personnel who should be interviewed.
justifications.D:
After the business process is identified, the IS auditor should first identify the control objectives and
activities associated with the business process that should be validated in the audit.

questions.question:
The effect of which of the following should have priority when planning the scope and objectives of an
information systems (IS) audit?

options.A: Applicable statutory requirements
options.B: Applicable corporate standards
options.C: Applicable industry good practices
options.D: Organizational policies and procedures

justifications.A:
The effect of applicable statutory requirements must be factored in while planning an information
systems (IS) audit—the IS auditor has no options regarding statutory requirements because there
can be no limitation of scope relating to statutory requirements.
justifications.B: Statutory requirements always take priority over corporate standards.
justifications.C:
Industry good practices help plan an audit; however, good practices are not mandatory and can be
deviated from, to meet organization objectives.
justifications.D:
Organizational policies and procedures are important, but statutory requirements always take priority.
Organizational policies must be in alignment with statutory requirements.
64 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
An external information systems (IS) auditor discovers that systems in the scope of the audit were
implemented by an associate. In such a circumstance, IS audit management should:

options.A: remove the IS auditor from the engagement.
options.B: cancel the engagement.
options.C: disclose the issue to the client.
options.D: take steps to restore the IS auditor's independence.

justifications.A:
It is not necessary to withdraw the information systems (IS) auditor unless there is a statutory limitation,
which exists in certain countries.
justifications.B: Canceling the engagement is not required if properly disclosed and accepted.
justifications.C:
In circumstances in which the IS auditor's independence is impaired and the IS auditor continues
to be associated with the audit, the facts surrounding the issue of the IS auditor's independence
should be disclosed to the appropriate management and in the report
justifications.D:
This is not a feasible solution. The independence of the IS auditor cannot be restored while continuing to
conduct the audit.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is planning to evaluate the control design effectiveness that is related
to an automated billing process. Which of the following is the MOST effective approach for the auditor to
adopt?

options.A: Interview
options.B: Inquiry
options.C: Reperformance
options.D: Walk-through

justifications.A:
An interview is not as strong evidence as an observation or walk-throughs. In addition, personnel might
add some bias to interviews if they know they are being interviewed for an audit.
justifications.B:
Inquiry can be used to understand the controls in a process only if it is accompanied by verification of
evidence. However, interviewees might be biased if they know they are being audited.
justifications.C:
Reperformance is used to evaluate the operating effectiveness of the control rather than the design of the
control.
justifications.D:
Walk-throughs involve a combination of inquiry and inspection of evidence with respect to business
process controls. This is the most effective basis for evaluation of the design of the control because it
confirms that the control actually exists.
65
CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
Which of the following is the MAIN reason to perform a risk assessment in the planning phase of an
information systems (IS) audit?

options.A: To ensure that management concerns are addressed
options.B: To provide reasonable assurance that material items will be addressed
options.C: To ensure that the audit team will perform audits within budget
options.D: To develop audit program and procedures needed to perform the audit

justifications.A:
Management concerns have no bearing on the risk assessment process. If management has concerns and
wants the auditor to fbcus on a certain area, the auditor should ensure adequate time is allocated to
address the concerns.
justifications.B:
A risk assessment helps to focus the audit procedures on the highest risk areas included in the scope
of the audit. The concept of reasonable assurance is also important.
justifications.C:
A risk assessment is performed to determine where to place time and personnel resources, while budget
constraints are limited to time resources.
justifications.D:
A risk assessment is not used in the development of the audit program and procedures. However, the risk
assessment is used to allocate resources to audits.

questions.question:
Which of the following is MOST important to ensure before communicating the audit findings to top
management during the closing meeting?

options.A: Risk statement includes an explanation of a business impact
options.B: Findings are clearly tracked back to evidence
options.C: Recommendations address root causes of findings
options.D: Remediation plans are provided by responsible parties

justifications.A:
It is important to have a well-elaborated risk statement; however, it might not be relevant if the findings
are not accurate.
justifications.B:
Without adequate evidence, the findings hold no ground; therefore, this must be verified before
communicating the findings.
justifications.C:
It is important to address the root causes of the findings, and they may not be included in the report.
However, they might not be relevant if the findings are not accurate.
justifications.D:
In some cases, top management might expect to see remediation plans during debriefing of the findings;
however, the accuracy of findings should be proved first.
66 CIS A ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
The MAIN advantage of an information systems (IS) auditor directly extracting data from a general ledger
system is:

options.A: reduction of human resources needed to support the audit.
options.B: reduction in the time to have access to the information.
options.C: greater flexibility for the audit department.
options.D: greater assurance of data validity.

justifications.A:
Although the burden on human resources to support the audit may decrease if the information systems
(IS) auditor directly extracts the data, this advantage is not as significant as the increased data validity.
justifications.B:
This will not necessarily reduce the time to have access to the information, because time will need to be
scheduled for training and granting access.
justifications.C:
There may be more flexibility for the IS auditor to adjust the data extracts to meet various audit
requirements; however, this is not the main advantage.
justifications.D:
If the IS auditor executes the data extraction, there is greater assurance that the extraction criteria
will not interfere with the required completeness, and, therefore, all required data will be collected.
Asking IT to extract the data may expose the risk of filtering out exceptions that should be seen
by the auditor. Also, if the IS auditor collects the data, all internal references correlating the
various data tables/elements will be understood, and this knowledge may reveal vital elements to
the completeness and correctness of the overall audit activity.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor wants to determine the number of purchase orders that are not
appropriately approved. Which of the following sampling techniques should an IS auditor use to make such a
conclusion?

options.A: Attribute
options.B: Variable
options.C: Stop-or-go
options.D: Judgment

justifications.A:
Attribute sampling is used to test compliance of transactions to controls—in this instance, the
existence of appropriate approval.
justifications.B:
Variable sampling is used in substantive testing situations and deals with population characteristics that
vary, such as monetary values and weights.
justifications.C: Stop-or-go sampling is used when the expected occurrence rate is extremely low.
justifications.D:
Judgment sampling is not relevant here. It refers to a subjective approach of determining sample size and
selection criteria of elements of the sample.
67
CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor uses computer-assisted audit techniques (CAATs) to collect and analyze
data. Which of the following attributes of evidence is MOST affected by using CAATs?

options.A: Usefulness
options.B: Reliability
options.C: Relevance
options.D: Adequacy

justifications.A:
Usefulness of audit evidence pulled by computer-assisted audit techniques (CAATs) is determined by the
audit objective, and the use of CAATs does not have as direct of an impact on usefulness as reliability.
justifications.B:
Because the data are directly collected by the information systems (IS) auditor, the audit findings
can be reported with an emphasis on the reliability of the records that are produced and maintained
in the system. The reliability of the source of information used provides reassurance on the
generated findings.
justifications.C:
Relevance of audit evidence pulled by CAATs is determined by the audit objective, and the use of CAATs
does not have as direct of an impact on relevance as reliability.
justifications.D:
Adequacy of audit evidence pulled by CAATs is determined by the processes and personnel who author
the data, and the use of CAATs does not have any impact on competence.

questions.question:
An internal information systems (IS) audit function is planning a general IS audit. Which of the following
activities takes place during the FIRST step of the planning phase?

options.A: Developing an audit program
options.B: Defining the audit scope
options.C: Identifying key information owners
options.D: Developing a risk assessment

justifications.A: The results of the risk assessment are used for the input for the audit program.
justifications.B: The output of the risk assessment helps define the scope.
justifications.C:
A risk assessment must be performed prior to identifying key information owners. Key information
owners are generally not directly involved during the planning process of an audit.
justifications.D:
A risk assessment should be performed to determine how internal audit resources should be
allocated to ensure that all material items will be addressed.
68 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition

questions.question:
Which of the fallowing is the MOST important skill that an information systems (IS) auditor should develop
to understand the constraints of conducting an audit?

options.A: Managing audit staff
options.B: Allocating resources
options.C: Project management
options.D: Attention to detail

justifications.A: Managing audit staff is not the only aspect of conducting an audit.
justifications.B: Allocating resources, such as time and personnel, is needed for overall project management skills.
justifications.C:
Audits often involve resource management, deliverables, scheduling and deadlines that are similar
to project management good practices.
justifications.D: Attention to detail is needed, but it is not a constraint of conducting audits.

questions.question: What is the MAJOR benefit of conducting a control self-assessment (CSA) over a traditional audit?

options.A: It detects risk sooner.
options.B: It replaces the internal audit function.
options.C: It reduces the audit workload.
options.D: It reduces audit resource requirements.

justifications.A:
Control self-assessments (CSAs) require employees to assess the control stature of their own
function. CSAs help to increase the understanding of business risk and internal controls. Because
they are conducted more frequently than audits, CSAs help to identify risk in a timelier manner.
justifications.B:
CSAs do not replace the internal audit function; an audit must still be performed to ensure that controls
are present.
justifications.C:
CSAs may not reduce the audit function's workload and are not a major difference between the two
approaches.
justifications.D:
CSAs do not affect the need for audit resources. Although the results of the CSA may serve as a reference
point for the audit process, they do not affect the scope or depth of audit work that needs to be performed.
69
CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is reviewing a project risk assessment and notices that the overall residual
risk level is high due to confidentiality requirements. Which of the following types of risk is normally high
due to the number of unauthorized users the project may affect?

options.A: Control risk
options.B: Compliance risk
options.C: Inherent risk
options.D: Residual risk

justifications.A:
Control risk can be high, but it is not due to internal controls not being identified, evaluated or tested, and
is not due to the number of users or business areas affected.
justifications.B:
Compliance risk is the penalty applied to current and future earnings for nonconformance to laws and
regulations and may not be impacted by the number of users and business areas affected.
justifications.C:
Inherent risk is normally high due to the number of users and business areas that may be affected.
Inherent risk is the risk level or exposure without considering the actions that management has
taken or might take.
justifications.D:
Residual risk is the remaining risk after management has implemented a risk response and is not based on
the number of users or business areas affected.

questions.question: An information systems (IS) auditor discovers a potential material finding. The BEST course of action is to:

options.A: report the potential finding to business management.
options.B: discuss the potential finding with the audit committee.
options.C: increase the scope of the audit.
options.D: perform additional testing.

justifications.A: The item should be confirmed through additional testing before it is reported to management.
justifications.B: The item should be confirmed through additional testing before it is discussed with the audit committee.
justifications.C:
Additional testing to confirm the potential finding should be within the scope of the engagement.
Increasing the scope can demand more needed audit resources and can be subject to risk creep.
justifications.D:
The information systems (IS) auditor should perform additional testing to ensure that it is a
finding. An auditor can quickly lose credibility if it is later discovered that the finding was not
justified or accurate.
70 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition

questions.question: Which of the following is in the BEST position to approve changes to the audit charter?

options.A: Board of directors
options.B: Audit committee
options.C: Executive management
options.D: Director of internal audit

justifications.A:
The board of directors does not need to approve the charter; it is best presented to the audit committee for
approval.
justifications.B:
The audit committee is a subgroup of the board of directors. The audit department should report to
the audit committee and the audit charter should be approved by the committee.
justifications.C:
Executive management is not required to approve the audit charter and will not have the independence
to approve the charter. The audit committee is in the best position to approve the charter because it is an
independent and senior group.
justifications.D:
Although the director of internal audit may draft the charter and make changes, the audit committee
should have the final approval of the charter.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor reviewing the process of log monitoring wants to evaluate the
organization's manual review process. Which of the following audit techniques would the auditor MOST
likely employ to fulfill this purpose?

options.A: Inspection
options.B: Inquiry
options.C: Walk-through
options.D: Reperformance

justifications.A:
Inspection is just one component of a walk-through and by itself does not supply enough information to
provide a full understanding of the overall process and identify potential control weaknesses.
justifications.B:
Inquiry provides only general information on how the control is executed. It does not necessarily
enable the information systems (IS) auditor to determine whether the control performer has an in-depth
understanding of the control.
justifications.C:
Walk-through procedures usually include a combination of inquiry, observation, inspection of
relevant documentation and reperformance of controls. A walk-through of the manual log review
process follows the manual log review process from start to finish to gain a thorough understanding
of the overall process and identify potential control weaknesses.
justifications.D:
Reperformance of the control is carried out by the IS auditor and does not provide assurance of the
competency of the auditee.
71
