©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is comparing equipment in production with inventory records. This type
of testing is an example of:

options.A: substantive testing.
options.B: compliance testing.
options.C: analytical testing.
options.D: control testing.

justifications.A:
Substantive testing obtains audit evidence on the completeness, accuracy or existence of activities or
transactions during the audit period.
justifications.B:
Compliance testing is evidence gathering for the purpose of testing an enterprise's compliance with
control procedures. This differs from substantive testing in which evidence is gathered to evaluate the
integrity of individual transactions, data or other information.
justifications.C:
Analytical testing evaluates the relationship of two sets of data and discerns inconsistencies in the
relationship.
justifications.D: Control testing is the same as compliance testing.

questions.question: Which of the following does a lack of adequate controls represent?

options.A: An impact
options.B: A vulnerability
options.C: An asset
options.D: A threat

justifications.A:
Impact is the measure of the consequence (including financial loss, reputational damage and loss of
customer confidence) that a threat event may have.
justifications.B:
The lack of adequate controls represents a vulnerability, exposing sensitive information and data
to the risk of malicious damage, attack or unauthorized access by hackers, employee error,
environmental threat, or equipment failure. This can result in a loss of sensitive information,
financial loss, legal penalties or other losses.
justifications.C:
An asset is something of either tangible or intangible value worth protecting, including people, systems,
infrastructure, finances and reputation.
justifications.D:
A threat is a potential cause of an unwanted incident.
72 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor notes daily reconciliation of visitor access card inventory is not aligned
with the organization's procedures. Which of the following is the auditor's BEST course of action?

options.A: Do not report the lack of reconciliation.
options.B: Recommend regular physical inventory counts.
options.C: Report the lack of daily reconciliations.
options.D: Recommend the implementation of a more secure access system.

justifications.A:
Absence of discrepancy in physical count only confirms absence of any impact but cannot be a reason
to overlook failure of operation of the control. The issue should be reported because the control was not
followed.
justifications.B:
Although the information systems (IS) auditor may in some cases recommend a change in procedures, the
primary goal is to observe and report when the current process is deficient.
justifications.C:
The IS auditor should report the lack of daily reconciliation as an exception because a physical
inventory count gives assurance only at a point in time and the practice is not in compliance with
management-mandated activity.
justifications.D:
Although the IS auditor may in some cases recommend a more secure solution, the primary goal is to
observe and report when the current process is deficient.

questions.question:
During an audit, the information systems (IS) auditor notes that the application developer also performs
quality assurance testing on another application. Which of the following is the MOST important course of
action for the auditor?

options.A: Recommend compensating controls.
options.B: Review the code created by the developer.
options.C: Analyze the quality assurance dashboards.
options.D: Report the identified condition.

justifications.A:
Although compensating controls may be a good idea, the primary response in this case should be to report
the condition, because the risk associated with this should be reported to the users of the audit report.
justifications.B:
Evaluating the code created by the application developer is not the appropriate response in this case. The
information systems (IS) auditor may evaluate a sample of changes to determine whether the developer
tested his/her own code, but the primary response should be to report the condition.
justifications.C:
Analyzing the quality assurance dashboards can help evaluate the actual impact of the lack of separation
of duties but does not address the underlying risk. The primary response should be to report the condition.
justifications.D:
The software quality assurance role should be independent from development and development
activities. The same person should not hold both roles, because this causes a separation of duties
concern. The IS auditor should report this condition when identified.
73
CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is reviewing risk and controls of the wire transfer system of a bank.
To ensure that the bank financial risk is properly addressed, the IS auditor most likely reviews which of the
following?

options.A: Privileged access to the wire transfer system
options.B: Wire transfer procedures
options.C: Fraud monitoring controls
options.D: Employee background checks

justifications.A:
Privileged access, such as administrator access, is necessary to manage user account privileges and should
not be granted to end users. The wire transfer procedures are a better control to review to ensure that there
is separation of duties of the end users to help prevent fraud.
justifications.B:
Wire transfer procedures include separation of duties controls. This helps prevent internal fraud
by not allowing one person to initiate, approve and send a wire. Therefore, the information systems
(IS) auditor should review the procedures as they relate to the wire system.
justifications.C:
Fraud monitoring is a detective control and does not prevent financial loss. Separation of duties is a
preventive control which is part of the wire transfer procedures.
justifications.D:
Although controls related to background checks are important, the controls related to separation of duties
as found in the wire transfer procedures are more critical.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is determining the appropriate sample size for testing the existence of
program change approvals. Previous audits did not indicate any exceptions, and management has confirmed
that no exceptions have been reported for the review period. In this context, the IS auditor can adopt a:

options.A: lower confidence coefficient, resulting in a smaller sample size.
options.B: higher confidence coefficient, resulting in a smaller sample size.
options.C: higher confidence coefficient, resulting in a larger sample size.
options.D: lower confidence coefficient, resulting in a larger sample size.

justifications.A:
When internal controls are strong, a lower confidence coefficient can be adopted, which will enable
the use of a smaller sample size.
justifications.B: A higher confidence coefficient will result in the use of a larger sample size.
justifications.C: A higher confidence coefficient need not be adopted in this situation because internal controls are strong.
justifications.D:
A lower confidence coefficient will result in the use of a smaller sample size.
74
CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
Why does an audit manager review the staff audit papers, even when the information systems (IS) auditors
have many years of experience?

options.A: Internal quality requirements
options.B: Audit guidelines
options.C: Audit methodology
options.D: Professional standards

justifications.A:
Internal quality requirements may exist but are superseded by the requirement of supervision to comply
with professional standards.
justifications.B:
Audit guidelines exist to provide guidance on how to achieve compliance with professional standards.
For example, they may provide insights on the purpose of supervision and examples of how supervisory
duties are to be performed to achieve compliance with professional standards.
justifications.C:
An audit methodology is a well-configured process/procedure to achieve audit objectives. Although an
audit methodology is a meaningful tool, supervision is generally driven by compliance with professional
standards.
justifications.D:
Professional standards from ISACA, The Institute of Internal Auditors (IIA) and the International
Federation of Accountants (IFA) require supervision of audit staff to accomplish audit objectives
and comply with competence, professional proficiency and documentation requirements, and more.

questions.question:
Which technique BEST tests for the existence of dual control when auditing the wire transfer systems of a
bank?

options.A: Analysis of transaction logs
options.B: Reperformance
options.C: Observation
options.D: Interviewing personnel

justifications.A:
Analysis of transaction logs helps to show that dual control is in place but does not necessarily guarantee
that this process is being followed consistently. Therefore, observation is the better test technique.
justifications.B:
Although reperformance can provide assurance that dual control was in effect, reperforming wire transfers
at a bank is not be an option for an information systems (IS) auditor.
justifications.C:
Dual control requires that two people carry out an operation. The observation technique helps to
ascertain whether two individuals do get involved in execution of the operation and an element of
oversight exists. It is obvious if one individual is masquerading and filling in the role of the second
person.
justifications.D:
Interviewing personnel is useful to determine the level of awareness and understanding of the personnel
carrying out the operations. However, it does provide direct evidence confirming the existence of dual
control, because the information provided may not accurately reflect the process being performed.
75
C/SA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
In a risk-based information systems (IS) audit, where both inherent and control risk have been assessed as
high, an IS auditor would MOST likely compensate for this scenario by performing additional:

options.A: stop-or-go sampling.
options.B: substantive testing.
options.C: compliance testing.
options.D: discovery sampling.

justifications.A:
Stop-or-go sampling is used when an information systems (IS) auditor believes few errors will be found
in the population and, thus, is not the best type of testing to perform in this case.
justifications.B:
Because both the inherent and control risk are high in this case, additional testing is required.
Substantive testing obtains audit evidence on the completeness, accuracy, or existence of activities
or transactions during the audit period.
justifications.C:
Compliance testing is evidence gathering for the purpose of testing an enterprise's compliance
with control procedures. Although performing compliance testing is important, performing additional
substantive testing is more appropriate in this case.
justifications.D:
Discovery sampling is a form of attribute sampling that is used to determine a specified probability of
finding at least one example of an occurrence (attribute) in a population, typically used to test for fraud or
other irregularities. In this case, additional substantive testing is the better option.

questions.question: The PRIMARY objective of the audit initiation meeting with an information systems (IS) audit client is to:

options.A: discuss the scope of the audit.
options.B: identify resource requirements of the audit.
options.C: select the methodology of the audit.
options.D: collect audit evidence.

justifications.A:
The primary objective of the initiation meeting with an audit client is to help define the scope of the
audit.
justifications.B:
Determining the resource requirements of the information systems (IS) audit is typically done by IS audit
management during the early planning phase of the project rather than at the initiation meeting.
justifications.C: Selecting the methodology of the audit is not normally an objective of the initiation meeting.
justifications.D:
For most audits, collecting audit evidence is performed during the course of the engagement and is not
normally collected during the initiation meeting.
76 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question: The PRIMARY purpose of the information systems (IS) audit charter is to:

options.A: establish the organizational structure of the audit department.
options.B: illustrate the reporting responsibilities of the IS audit function.
options.C: detail the resource requirements needed for the audit function.
options.D: outline the responsibility and authority of the IS audit function.

justifications.A:
The information systems (IS) audit charter does not set forth the organizational structure of the IS audit
department. The charter serves as a directive to create the IS audit function.
justifications.B:
The IS audit charter does not dictate the reporting requirements of the IS audit department. The charter
sets forth the purpose, responsibility, authority and accountability of the information systems audit
function.
justifications.C: Resources are determined by the audit and not the charter.
justifications.D:
The primary purpose of the IS audit charter is to set forth the purpose, responsibility, authority
and accountability of the IS audit function. The charter document grants authority to the audit
function on behalf of the board of directors and organization stakeholders.

questions.question:
Which of the following is MOST important for an information systems (IS) auditor to understand when
auditing an ecommerce environment?

options.A: The technology architecture of the ecommerce environment
options.B: The policies, procedures and practices forming the control environment
options.C: The nature and criticality of the business processes supported by the application
options.D: Continuous monitoring of control measures for system availability and reliability

justifications.A:
Understanding the technology architecture of the ecommerce environment is important; however, it is
vital that the nature and criticality of the business process supported by the ecommerce application are
well understood.
justifications.B:
Although the policies, procedure and practices that form the internal control environment need to be in
alignment with the ecommerce environment, this is not the most important element that the information
systems (IS) auditor needs to understand.
justifications.C:
The ecommerce application enables the execution of business transactions. Therefore, it is
important to understand the nature and criticality of the business processes supported by the
ecommerce application to identify specific controls to review.
justifications.D:
The availability of the ecommerce environment is important, but this is only one of the aspects to be
considered with respect to business processes that are supported by the ecommerce application.
77
CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
During an information systems (IS) audit, which is the BEST method for an IS auditor to evaluate the
implementation of separation of duties within an IT department?

options.A: Discuss with the IT managers.
options.B: Review the IT job descriptions.
options.C: Research past IT audit reports.
options.D: Evaluate the organizational structure.

justifications.A:
Discussing the implementation of separation of duties with the IT managers is the best way to
determine how responsibilities are assigned within the department.
justifications.B:
Job descriptions may not be the best source of information because they can be outdated, or what is
documented in the job descriptions may be different from what is performed.
justifications.C:
Past information systems (IS) audit reports are not the best source of information because they may not
accurately describe how IT responsibilities are assigned.
justifications.D:
Evaluating the organizational structure may give a limited view on the allocation of IT responsibilities.
The responsibilities also may have changed over time.

questions.question:
A financial institution with multiple branch offices has an automated control that requires the branch manager
to approve transactions over a certain amount. What type of audit control is this?

options.A: Detective
options.B: Preventive
options.C: Corrective
options.D: Directive

justifications.A:
Detective controls identify events after they have happened. In this case, the action of the branch manager
prevents an event from occurring.
justifications.B: Having a manager approve transactions over a certain amount is considered a preventive control.
justifications.C:
A corrective control serves to remedy problems discovered by detective controls. In this case, the action
of the branch manager is a preventive control.
justifications.D:
A directive control is a manual control that typically consists of a policy or procedure that specifies what
actions are to be performed. In this case, an automated control prevents an event from occurring.
78 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question: During an application software review, an information systems (IS) auditor identified minor weaknesses in a relevant database environment that is out ofscope fbr the audit. The BEST option is to:

options.A: include a review ofthe database controls in the scope
options.B: document fbr future review.
options.C: work with database administrators to correct the issue
options.D: report the weaknesses as observed.

justifications.A: Executing audits and reviews outside the scope is not advisable. In this case, the weaknesses identified are considered to be a minor issue, and it is sufficient to report the issue and address it at a later time.
justifications.B: In this case, the weaknesses identified are considered to be a minor issue. The information systems (IS) auditor should formally report the weaknesses as an observation rather than documenting it to address during a future audit.
justifications.C: It is not appropriate fbr the IS auditor to work with database administrators to correct the issue.
justifications.D: Any weakness noticed should be reported, even ifit is outside the scope ofthe current audit. Weaknesses identified during an application software review need to be reported to management.

questions.question:
A centralized antivirus system determines whether each personal computer has the latest signature files and
installs the latest signature files before allowing a PC to connect to the network. This is an example of a:

options.A: directive control.
options.B: corrective control.
options.C: compensating control.
options.D: detective control.

justifications.A:
Directive controls, such as IT policies and procedures, do not apply in this case because this is an
automated control.
justifications.B:
Corrective controls are designed to correct errors, omissions and unauthorized uses and intrusions,
when they are detected. This provides a mechanism to detect when malicious events happen and
corrects the situation.
justifications.C:
A compensating control is used where other controls are not sufficient to protect the system. In this case,
the conective control in place effectively protects the system from access via an unpatched device.
justifications.D:
Detective controls exist to detect and report when errors, omissions and unauthorized uses or entries
occur.
79
CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
Due to unexpected resource constraints of the information systems (IS) audit team, the audit plan, as
originally approved, cannot be completed. Assuming that the situation is communicated in the audit report,
which course of action is MOST acceptable?

options.A: Test the adequacy of the control design.
options.B: Test the operational effectiveness of controls.
options.C: Focus on auditing high-risk areas.
options.D: Rely on management testing of controls.

justifications.A:
Testing the adequacy of control design is not the best course of action because this does not ensure that
controls operate effectively as designed.
justifications.B:
Testing control operating effectiveness does not ensure that the audit plan is focused on areas of greatest
risk.
justifications.C: Reducing the scope and focusing on auditing high-risk areas is the best course of action.
justifications.D:
The reliance on management testing of controls does not provide an objective verification of the control
environment.

questions.question:
Which of the following BEST ensures the effectiveness of controls related to interest calculation for an
accounting system?

options.A: Reperformance
options.B: Process walk-through
options.C: Observation
options.D: Documentation review

justifications.A:
To ensure the effectiveness of controls, it is most effective to conduct reperformance. When the
same result is obtained after the performance by an independent person, this provides the strongest
assurance.
justifications.B:
Process walk-through may help the auditor understand the controls better; however, it may not be as
useful as conducting reperformance for a sample of transactions.
justifications.C:
Observation is a valid audit method to verify that operators are using the system appropriately; however,
conducting reperformance is a better method.
justifications.D:
Documentation review may be of some value for understanding the control environment; however,
conducting reperformance is a better method.
80 C/SA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13比 Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question: Which of the following choices is the BEST source of information when developing a risk-based audit plan?

options.A: Process owners identify key controls.
options.B: System custodians identify vulnerabilities.
options.C: Peer auditors understand previous audit results.
options.D: Senior management identifies key business processes.

justifications.A:
Although process owners should be consulted to identify key controls, senior management is a better
source to identify business processes, which are more important.
justifications.B:
System custodians are a good source to better understand the risk and controls as they apply to specific
applications; however, senior management is a better source to identify business processes, which are
more important.
justifications.C:
The review of previous audit results is one input into the audit planning process; however, if previous
audits focused on a limited or a restricted scope, or if the key business processes have changed and/or
new business processes have been introduced, then this does contribute to the development of a risk-based
audit plan.
justifications.D:
Developing a risk-based audit plan must start with the identification of key business processes,
which determine and identify the risk that needs to be addressed.

questions.question:
While auditing a third-party IT service provider, an information systems (IS) auditor discovers that access
reviews are not being performed as required by the contract. The IS auditor should:

options.A: report the issue to IT management.
options.B: discuss the issue with the service provider.
options.C: perform a risk assessment.
options.D: perform an access review.

justifications.A:
During an audit, if there are material issues that are of concern, they need to be reported to
management in the audit report
justifications.B:
The information systems (IS) auditor may discuss the issue with the service provider; however, the
appropriate response is to report the issue to IT management because they are ultimately responsible.
justifications.C:
This issue can serve as an input for a future risk assessment, but the issue of noncompliance should be
reported to management regardless of whether the IS auditor believes there is a significant risk.
justifications.D:
The IS auditor can perform an access review as part of the audit to determine if there are errors, but not on
behalf of the third-party IT service provider. It is more important to report the issue in the audit report to
management.
81
CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
When the information systems (IS) auditor encounters instances or indicators of fraud during regular
assurance work, what should the IS auditor do FIRST?

options.A: Communicate with audit management.
options.B: Escalate the issue to the audit committee.
options.C: Report the fraud instance to appropriate authorities.
options.D: Exercise careful analysis and evaluation.

justifications.A:
The information systems (IS) auditor may communicate with audit management to get their
recommendations after exercising due professional care.
justifications.B:
After doing further analysis and evaluation, audit management should communicate with the audit
committee to consider the next step, especially if there is an indicator or instance of major fraud.
justifications.C:
Reporting to appropriate authorities should be done after exercising due professional care and consulting
audit management and the audit committee.
justifications.D:
The IS auditor must exercise due professional care and do further analysis and evaluation before
considering the issue an instance of fraud.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor performing an audit of the risk assessment process should FIRST
confirm that:

options.A: reasonable threats to information assets are identified.
options.B: technical and organizational vulnerabilities have been analyzed.
options.C: assets have been identified and ranked.
options.D: the effects of potential security breaches have been evaluated.

justifications.A:
The threats facing each of the organization's assets should be analyzed according to their value to the
organization. This occurs after identifying and ranking assets.
justifications.B:
Analyzing how these weaknesses, in the absence of mitigating controls, will impact the organization's
information assets occurs after the assets and weaknesses have been identified.
justifications.C:
Identification and ranking of information assets (e.g., data criticality, sensitivity, locations of assets)
sets the tone or scope of how to assess risk in relation to the organizational value of the asset
justifications.D:
The effect of security breaches is dependent on the value of the assets and the threats, vulnerabilities and
effectiveness of mitigating controls. The impact of an attack against a weakness should be identified so
that controls can be evaluated to determine if they effectively mitigate the weaknesses.
82 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question: Which of the following represents an example of a preventive control with respect to IT personnel?

options.A: A security guard stationed at the server room door
options.B: An intrusion detection system (IDS)
options.C: A badge entry system for the IT facility
options.D: A fire-suppression system in the server room

justifications.A: A security guard is a deterrent control.
justifications.B: An intrusion detection system (IDS) is a detective control.
justifications.C:
Preventive controls are used to reduce the probability of an adverse event. A badge entry system
prevents unauthorized entry to the facility.
justifications.D: A fire-suppression system is a corrective control.

questions.question: Which of the following is an attribute of the control self-assessment (CSA) approach?

options.A: Broad stakeholder involvement
options.B: Auditors are the primary control analysts
options.C: Limited employee participation
options.D: Policy-driven

justifications.A:
The control self-assessment (CSA) approach emphasizes management of and accountability for
developing and monitoring the controls of an organization's business processes. The attributes of
CSA include empowered employees, continuous improvement, extensive employee participation
and training一all of which are representations of broad stakeholder involvement.
justifications.B:
Information systems (IS) auditors are the primary control analysts in a traditional audit approach. CSA
involves many stakeholders, not just auditors.
justifications.C: Limited employee participation is an attribute of a traditional audit approach.
justifications.D:
Policy-driven is an attribute of a traditional audit approach.
83
CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations ManuaH3th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor conducting a review of disaster recovery planning (DRP) at a financial
processing organization discovers the following:
• The existing DRP was compiled two years earlier by a systems analyst in the organization's IT department
using transaction flow projections from the operations department.
• The DRP was presented to the deputy CEO for approval and formal issue, but it is still awaiting attention.
• The DRP has never been updated, tested or circulated to key management and staffs although interviews
show that each would know what action to take for its area if a disruptive incident occurred.
The IS auditor's report should recommend that:

options.A: the deputy CEO is censured for failure to approve the plan.
options.B: a group of senior managers is set up to review the existing plan.
options.C: the existing plan is approved and circulated to all key management and staff
options.D: a manager coordinates the creation of a new or revised plan within a defined time limit.

justifications.A:
Censuring the deputy CEO will not improve the current situation and is generally not within the scope of
an information systems (IS) auditor to recommend.
justifications.B:
Establishing a group to review the disaster recovery plan (DRP), which is two years out of date, may
achieve an updated DRP but is not likely to be a speedy operation; issuing the existing DRP would be
imprudent without first ensuring that it is workable.
justifications.C:
The current DRP may be unacceptable or ineffective and recommending the approval of the DRP may be
unwise. The best way to develop a DRP in a short time is to make an experienced manager responsible for
coordinating the knowledge of other managers into a single, formal document within a defined time limit.
justifications.D:
The primary concern is to establish a workable DRP that reflects current processing volumes to
protect the organization from any disruptive incident.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor finds that a disaster recovery plan (DRP) for critical business functions
does not cover all systems. Which of the following is the MOST appropriate course of action for the IS
auditor?

options.A: Alert management and evaluate the impact of not covering all systems.
options.B: Cancel the audit.
options.C: Complete the audit of the systems covered by the existing DRP.
options.D: Postpone the audit until the systems are added to the DRP.

justifications.A:
An information systems (IS) auditor should make management aware that some systems are
omitted from the disaster recovery plan (DRP). An IS auditor should continue the audit and include
an evaluation of the impact of not including all systems in the DRP.
justifications.B: Canceling the audit is an inappropriate action.
justifications.C:
Ignoring the feet that some systems are not covered violates audit standards that require reporting all
material findings and is an inappropriate action.
justifications.D:
Postponing the audit is an inappropriate action. The audit should be completed according to the initial
scope with identification to management of the risk of systems not being covered.
84
C/SA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question: Which of the following is MOST effective for monitoring transactions exceeding predetermined thresholds?

options.A: Generalized audit software (GAS)
options.B: An integrated test facility
options.C: Regression tests
options.D: Transaction snapshots

justifications.A:
Generalized audit software (GAS) is a data analytics tool that can be used to filter large amounts of
data.
justifications.B:
Integrated test facilities test the processing of the data and cannot be used to monitor real-time
transactions.
justifications.C:
Regression tests are used to test new versions of software to ensure that previous changes and
functionality are not inadvertently overwritten or disabled by the new changes.
justifications.D:
Gathering information through snapshots alone is not sufficient. GAS will assist with an analysis of the
data.

questions.question: Which of the following is MOST important to ensure that effective application controls are maintained?

options.A: Exception reporting
options.B: Manager oversight
options.C: Control self-assessment (CSA)
options.D: Peer reviews

justifications.A: Exception reporting only looks at errors or problems but will not ensure that controls are still working.
justifications.B:
Manager oversight is important but may not be a consistent or well-defined process compared to control
self-assessment.
justifications.C:
Control self-assessment (CSA) is the review of business objectives and internal controls in a formal
and documented collaborative process. It includes testing the design of automated application
controls.
justifications.D:
Peer reviews lack the direct involvement of audit specialists and management.
85
CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question: The success of a control self assessment (CSA) depends highly on:

options.A: line managers assuming a portion of the responsibility for control monitoring.
options.B: assigning staff managers the responsibility for building controls.
options.C: the implementation of a stringent control policy and rule-driven controls.
options.D: the implementation of supervision and monitoring of controls of assigned duties.

justifications.A:
The primary objective of a control self-assessment (CSA) program is to leverage the internal audit
function by shifting some of the control monitoring responsibilities to the functional area line
managers. The success of a CSA program depends on the degree to which line managers assume
responsibility for controls. This enables line managers to detect and respond to control errors
promptly.
justifications.B: CSA requires managers to participate in the monitoring of controls.
justifications.C: The implementation of stringent controls will not ensure controls are working correctly.
justifications.D:
Better supervision is a compensating and detective control and may assist in ensuring control
effectiveness but would work best when used in a formal process such as CSA.

questions.question:
Which of the following is evaluated as a preventive control by an information systems (IS) auditor performing
an audit?

options.A: Transaction logs
options.B: Before and after image reporting
options.C: Table lookups
options.D: Tracing and tagging

justifications.A: Transaction logs are a detective control and provide audit trails.
justifications.B:
Before and after image reporting makes it possible to trace the impact that transactions have on computer
records. This is a detective control.
justifications.C:
Table lookups are preventive controls; input data are checked against predefined tables, which
prevent any undefined data from being entered.
justifications.D:
Tracing and tagging is used to test application systems and controls but is not a preventive control in
itself.

questions.question:
Which of the following is a PRIMARY objective of embedding an audit module while developing online
application systems?

options.A: To collect evidence while transactions are processed
options.B: To reduce requirements for periodic internal audits
options.C: To identify and report fraudulent transactions
options.D: To increase efficiency of the audit function

justifications.A:
Embedding a module for continuous auditing within an application processing a large number
of transactions provides timely collection of audit evidence during processing and is the primary
objective. The continuous auditing approach allows the information systems (IS) auditor to monitor
system reliability on a continuous basis and to gather selective audit evidence through the computer.
justifications.B:
An embedded audit module enhances the effectiveness of internal audit by ensuring timely availability of
required evidence. It may not reduce the requirements for periodic internal audits, but it will increase their
efficiency. Also, the question pertains to the development process for new application systems, and not to
subsequent internal audits.
justifications.C:
An audit module collects data on transactions that may help identify fraudulent transactions, but it does
not identify fraudulent transactions inherently.
justifications.D:
Although increased efficiency may be an added benefit of an embedded audit module, it is not the primary
objective.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) audit department considers implementing continuous auditing techniques for
a multinational retail enterprise that requires high availability of its key systems. A PRIMARY benefit of
continuous auditing is that:

options.A: Effective preventive controls are enforced.
options.B: System integrity is ensured.
options.C: Errors can be corrected in a timely fashion.
options.D: Fraud can be detected more quickly.

justifications.A:
Continuous monitoring is detective in nature and, therefore, does not necessarily assist the information
systems (IS) auditor in monitoring for preventive controls. The approach will detect and monitor for
errors that have already occurred. In addition, continuous monitoring will benefit the internal audit
function in reducing the use of auditing resources and in the timely reporting of errors or inconsistencies.
justifications.B:
System integrity is typically associated with preventive controls, such as input controls and quality
assurance reviews. These controls do not typically benefit an internal auditing function implementing
continuous monitoring. Continuous monitoring benefits the internal audit function because it reduces the
use of auditing resources.
justifications.C:
Continuous audit will detect errors but not correct them. Correcting errors is the function of the
organization's management and not the internal audit function. Continuous auditing benefits the internal
audit fiinction because it reduces the use of auditing resources to create a more efficient auditing function.
justifications.D:
Continuous auditing techniques assist the auditing function in reducing the use of auditing
resources through continuous collection of evidence. This approach assists the IS auditors in
identifying fraud in a timely fashion and allows the auditors to focus on relevant data.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor wants to determine the effectiveness of managing user access to a server
room. Which of the following is the BEST evidence of effectiveness?

options.A: Observation of a logged event
options.B: Review of the procedure manual
options.C: Interview with management
options.D: Interview with security personnel

justifications.A:
Observation of the process to reset an employee's security access to the server room and the
subsequent logging of this event provide the best evidence of the adequacy of the physical security
control.
justifications.B:
Although reviewing the procedure manual can be helpful in gaining an overall understanding of a process,
it is not evidence of the effectiveness of the execution of a control.
justifications.C:
Although interviewing management can be helpful in gaining an overall understanding of a process, it is
not evidence of the effectiveness of the execution of a control.
justifications.D:
Although interviewing security personnel can be helpful in gaining an overall understanding of a process,
it is not evidence of the effectiveness of the execution of a control.

questions.question:
As part of audit planning, an information systems (IS) auditor is designing various data validation tests to
effectively detect transposition and transcription errors. Which of the following will BEST help in detecting
these errors?

options.A: Range check
options.B: Validity check
options.C: Duplicate check
options.D: Check digit

justifications.A:
Range checks can only ensure that data fall within a predetermined range but cannot detect transposition
errors.
justifications.B:
Validity checks are generally programmed checking of data validity in accordance with predetermined
criteria.
justifications.C: Duplicate check analysis is used to test defined or selected primary keys for duplicate primary key values.
justifications.D:
A check digit is a numeric value that has been calculated mathematically and is added to data to
ensure that original data have not been altered or that an incorrect, but valid, match has occurred.
The check digit control is effective in detecting transposition and transcription errors.

questions.question: The MAIN purpose of the annual information systems (IS) audit plan is to:

options.A: allocate resources for audits.
options.B: reduce the impact of audit risk.
options.C: develop a training plan for auditors.
options.D: minimize the audit costs.

justifications.A:
Because information systems (IS) audit assignments need to be accomplished with limited time and
human resources, audits are scheduled and prioritized as determined by IS audit management.
justifications.B: Audit risk is inherent to all audits, and the schedule has no bearing on the impact to audit risk.
justifications.C: Developing a training plan for auditors is important, but it is not the main purpose of an IS audit plan.
justifications.D:
Minimizing the audit costs could be one of the objectives of an annual IS audit plan. However, this would
be a result of ensuring audit resources are used effectively.

questions.question: Which of the following is expected to approve the audit charter?

options.A: Chief financial officer
options.B: CEO
options.C: Audit steering committee
options.D: Audit committee

justifications.A:
The chief financial officer (CFO) does not approve the audit charter but may be responsible for allocating
funds in support of the audit charter. The CFO may also be a part of the audit committee or audit steering
committee but would not approve the charter alone.
justifications.B:
The CEO does not approve the audit charter. The CEO may be informed but is independent of the audit
committee.
justifications.C:
The steering committee is most likely composed of various members of senior management whose
purpose is to work under the framework of the audit charter and does not approve the charter.
justifications.D: One of the primary functions of the audit committee is to create and approve the audit charter.

questions.question: Which of the following is the PRIMARY purpose of a risk-based audit?

options.A: High-impact areas are addressed first.
options.B: Audit resources are allocated efficiently.
options.C: Material areas are addressed first.
options.D: Management concerns are prioritized.

justifications.A: High impact does not necessarily indicate high risk. Risk also takes into consideration probability.
justifications.B:
Although a risk-based audit approach does address allocation of resources, that is not the primary function
of a risk-based audit approach.
justifications.C:
Material risk is audited according to the risk ranking, thus enabling the audit team to concentrate
on high-risk areas first.
justifications.D:
Management concerns may not be aligned with high-risk areas.

questions.question:
An auditee disagrees with an audit finding. Which of the following is the BEST course of action for the
information systems (IS) auditor to take?

options.A: Discuss the finding with the IS auditor's manager.
options.B: Retest the control to confirm the finding.
options.C: Elevate the risk associated with the control.
options.D: Discuss the finding with the auditee's manager.

justifications.A:
Discussing the disagreement with the auditor's manager is the best course of action because other
actions can weaken relationships with the auditee and auditor
justifications.B:
This may unnecessarily expend human and time resources. The audit manager should determine if
controls need to be retested.
justifications.C: Elevating the risk does not address the disagreement.
justifications.D:
It is usually best to consult the audit manager prior to escalating the issue to the auditee's manager. This
could prove to be an adversarial action.

questions.question: The data owners are responsible for:

options.A: safeguarding the data by creating regular backups.
options.B: security of data throughout their life cycle from origination to destruction.
options.C: protecting the data by monitoring them in real time.
options.D: performing risk assessment and implementing appropriate controls.

justifications.A: The data owners generally do not create the backups but define the requirements for data backup.
justifications.B: The data owners are primarily responsible for safeguarding the data they own.
justifications.C:
The data owners generally do not monitor the data communication but define the data monitoring
requirements for the custodian or other responsible personnel.
justifications.D:
The data owners generally do not perform the risk assessment but define the risk management
requirements.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor realizes that the skilled resources required to test the specific technical
controls are only available for a limited period during an IS audit; therefore, comprehensive testing of all audit
areas may not be possible. Which of the following is the BEST course of action for the auditor?

options.A: Execute the audit focusing on critical areas where skilled resources are used to test controls.
options.B: Have audit management request skilled resources for the entire audit period.
options.C: Refuse to conduct the audit unless skilled resources are available for the entire audit period.
options.D: Extend the timelines of the audit project for training to enhance the skills of the audit team.

justifications.A:
In a situation where limited resources are available; an auditor may use the services of skilled
resources for high-risk audit areas to ensure that the maximum number of controls in high-risk
areas are tested.
justifications.B:
Auditors may escalate the issue to audit management, but, in the case of unavailable resources, it is best to
address high-risk areas first.
justifications.C:
Refusing to conduct an audit may not be a reasonable solution and will cause control failures or
weaknesses in high-risk areas to remain undetected.
justifications.D:
It is useful to have the audit team increase their knowledge and skills; however, this option may not be
reasonable to auditee management.

questions.question:
Which of the following is the BEST source of information that the information systems (IS) auditor can use in
assessing the process being audited?

options.A: Interviews with a sample of employees from the IT department
options.B: Current audit plan
options.C: Past audit reports
options.D: Recent control self-assessment

justifications.A:
Interviews with some employees will help the information systems (IS) auditor to better understand
processes and capture any missing items from the control self-assessment (CSA). However, this is not the
best source of information.
justifications.B:
The audit plan is created after understanding the business risk within the audit scope. Therefore, it will not
help to identify higher-risk processes.
justifications.C:
Past audit reports can be another source of information. However, the enterprise could have had changes
since that last audit. Therefore, a recently completed control self-assessment will be the best source of
information that an IS auditor reviews.
justifications.D:
CSA is made by the staff and management of the unit involved. This assessment can be used by the
IS auditor to identify higher-risk processes and then link them to the applications being used.

questions.question: Which of the following is the MOST essential input required for a risk-based audit planning?

options.A: Internal controls and procedures description
options.B: Action report on previous years' audit findings
options.C: Information security policies and procedures
options.D: Availability of resources and project timeline

justifications.A:
Although all the answers are useful for risk-based audit planning, a description of internal controls
and procedures is the most essential input required in planning control testing based on the
risk being mitigated. The higher the risk, the more detailed testing required. This will help in
determining the priority of the audit areas.
justifications.B:
Repeat findings from previous audit reports may represent higher risk; however, that information is useful
in reporting rather than planning.
justifications.C:
Security policies and procedures help in determining the security controls to be tested during the security
audit planning and may not directly help in risk-based audit planning.
justifications.D:
The availability of resources and audit project timelines are required for risk-based audit planning. This
information helps provide skilled resources for prioritized audit areas but is not the most essential input
required.

questions.question:
Which of the following should be the FIRST step for the information systems (IS) auditor to take when
planning for an audit?

options.A: Understand internal controls.
options.B: Perform compliance tests.
options.C: Gather information and plan.
options.D: Perform substantive tests.

justifications.A: Understanding internal controls comes after information gathering.
justifications.B: Compliance and substantive tests are performed during the audit.
justifications.C:
The first step in planning an audit is gathering information to understand the business and industry
(e.g., prior year audits, recent financial information, inherent risk assessments).
justifications.D:
Compliance and substantive tests are performed during the audit.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is assigned to review an enterprise's network; however, the auditor is not
comfortable with executing a vulnerability assessment. Which of the following would be the BEST approach
for the auditor?

options.A: Request a change of scope to exclude a vulnerability assessment.
options.B: Hire independent experts with consent from the authorities.
options.C: Refuse to conduct the audit due to a competency issue.
options.D: Proceed to conduct vulnerability assessment with limited skills and lack of needed competencies.

justifications.A:
Reducing scope by excluding the vulnerability assessment will impact the achievement of the audit
objectives and is, therefore, not a viable option.
justifications.B:
Practitioners who do not have the required competencies to perform the audit engagement, either
in whole or in part, should seek assistance from independent experts with consent from the
authorities who signed the audit charter.
justifications.C:
Refusing to conduct an audit or requesting to pass it on to another auditor is an option but not as good as
hiring an independent expert.
justifications.D:
Conducting a vulnerability assessment without needed skills and competencies is against professional
ethics.

While auditing database logs for a client, an information systems (IS) auditor needs to verify their redundant

options.B: Ignore the backup on the cloud because it is already a verbatim copy.

options.D: Inform the client about the suggested modification in the original project plan.

The audit engagement project plan should be updated and changed as necessary (with appropriate
approvals by IT audit and assurance management) during the audit engagement.

questions.question:
While performing the review of the sampled exception transactions report, which of the following is the
MOST appropriate indicator to move from compliance testing to substantive testing for an information
systems (IS) auditor?

options.A: Control documentation
options.B: Log analysis
options.C: System requirements specifications
options.D: Data flow diagrams

justifications.A: Controls can be well documented, but that does not automatically put them in place.
justifications.B:
Log analysis of posting and approval of exceptional transactions can lead to missing or ineffective
controls, which may further require substantive sampling.
justifications.C:
System requirements specifications record functional and nonfunctional requirements, but also need
validation.
justifications.D:
Data flow diagrams are not as effective as log analysis, because they do not necessarily identify and
assess all control issues.

questions.question: What is a KEY benefit of incorporating data analytics into the audit process?

options.A: Identification of patterns and trends in data for risk assessment
options.B: Elimination of the need for audit testing and sampling
options.C: Reduction of audit scope and reliance on internal controls
options.D: Addition of work for auditors to learn data analysis tools

justifications.A:
Incorporating data analytics into the audit process enables auditors to analyze large volumes of
data efficiently and effectively. One of the key benefits of using data analytics is the ability to
identify patterns and trends in data, which can provide valuable insights for risk assessment. By
analyzing data, auditors can detect anomalies, assess the effectiveness of controls and identify
potential areas of risk or noncompliance. Incorporating data analytics into the audit process brings
several benefits, but a key benefit is enhanced decision-making.
justifications.B:
Although data analytics can enhance the audit process, it does not eliminate the need for audit testing and
sampling.
justifications.C:
Data analytics does not directly reduce the audit scope but, instead, helps auditors fbcus their efforts on
areas of higher risk and significance.
justifications.D:
Although data analytics can enhance the audit process, it does not replace auditors with the use of
automated tools. Using a data analytics tool may require some learning by auditors; however, it may
reduce the workload in the long term.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor observes a potential zero-day exposure when performing a vulnerability
assessment at a client site. Which of the following is the BEST approach that the IS auditor should take?

options.A: Annotate the findings and properly document the same in the audit report.
options.B: Immediately consult the client system administrator to alter the firewall rules.
options.C: Immediately consult the client developer to patch the system.
options.D: Immediately discuss the findings with the auditee's management along with evidence.

justifications.A:
Prior to reporting, the information systems (IS) auditor should consult with the auditee and develop a
remediation plan for the zero-day exploit.
justifications.B:
The root cause needs to be identified and the auditee's management must be notified prior to any
alternation to the network and systems.
justifications.C:
The root cause needs to be identified and the auditee's management must be notified prior to any
alternation to systems.
justifications.D:
The IS auditor should discuss the findings with auditee's management to gain agreement on the
findings and develop an agreed-on course of corrective action.

questions.question:
An enterprise adopted a policy of periodic verification of IT assets through control self-assessment (CSA).
Which of the following is the BEST approach for an information systems (IS) auditor of the enterprise?

options.A: The IS auditor should actively participate in the CSA for asset verification.
options.B: The IS auditor should suggest that the enterprise incentivize the CSA exercise.
options.C: The IS auditor should review the CSA outcome and look for other internal controls in place.
options.D: The IS auditor should recuse from the CSA exercise, citing repetition/redundancy of work.

justifications.A: The auditor should act as a facilitator, not an audit participant.
justifications.B:
Control sei仁assessment (CSA) should not be considered an extra activity and should not be linked with
monetary benefits for motivation.
justifications.C:
CSA alone may be mistaken as an audit function replacement; therefore, internal controls must
exist and the IS auditor must look for them.
justifications.D:
CSA cannot replace the audit function.

questions.question:
Which of the following is the BEST approach for an information systems (IS) auditor evaluating IT-related
controls as a member of an integrated audit team?

options.A: Perform IT audits independently and submit findings to the audit manager to include in the final report.
options.B: Prioritize control testing based on the complexity of the technology implemented by the enterprise.
options.C: Include in the audit report the impact to the business due to weaknesses found in IT controls.
options.D: Discuss the findings with the audit manager and afterwards submit the IT audit report to auditee's

justifications.A:
The IT audit may be performed independently; however, describing the business impact will help the
audit manager prepare meaningful and comprehensive audit reporting.
justifications.B:
Prioritization of control testing based on the risk to the business is a better approach than just focusing on
the complexity of implemented technology.
justifications.C:
One of the objectives of an integrated audit is to provide added value to the auditee and improve the
overall quality of the audit process. Describing the business impact due to weaknesses in IT-related
controls best helps the auditee management in relating the deployment of IT with the business.
justifications.D:
Discussing findings with the audit manager may be appropriate; however, it may not be effective unless
the impact has been described in business terms.

questions.question:
Which of the following is the PRIMARY objective of a quality assurance (QA) and improvement program
for an audit process?

options.A: To ensure that all audit findings are accepted, addressed and resolved on time
options.B: To provide a basis for evaluating the effectiveness and efficiency of the audit process
options.C: To ensure that auditors are adequately trained, qualified and competent to perform audits
options.D: To establish standard procedures for conducting audits, analyzing evidence and reporting findings

justifications.A:
Although ensuring that audit findings are addressed and resolved on time is an important aspect of quality
assurance (QA), it is not the primary objective.
justifications.B:
A QA and improvement program for an audit process is designed to evaluate the effectiveness
and efficiency of the audit process and identify areas for improvement. This can be achieved
through various activities, such as conducting internal reviews and assessments, benchmarking
against industry standards, and soliciting stakeholder feedback. The primary objective of a QA
and improvement program for an audit process is to ensure that the audit activities are conducted
consistently, accurately and efficiently. This involves confirming that the audit processes align with
professional standards, regulatory requirements, and the enterprise's policies and objectives.
justifications.C:
Ensuring that auditors are adequately trained and qualified is important but not the primary objective of a
quality assurance and improvement program.
justifications.D:
Establishing standard procedures is important but not the primary objective of a quality assurance and
improvement program.

questions.question:
Which of the following is the MOST important factor in ensuring the success of a new audit quality assurance
(QA) program?

options.A: Using a systematic approach to develop the program
options.B: Defining clear and measurable objectives and goals
options.C: Ensuring that continuous improvement efforts are embedded in the program
options.D: Obtaining commitment and support from senior management

justifications.A:
Using a systematic approach is one factor in developing the quality assurance (QA) program, but the most
important factor is the commitment of the enterprise's senior management.
justifications.B:
Identifying the objective criteria is one factor in developing the quality assurance program, but the most
important factor is the commitment of the enterprise's senior management.
justifications.C:
Continuous improvement is an important factor in developing the QA program, but the most important
factor is the commitment of the enterprise's senior management.
justifications.D:
The success of any QA program depends on the commitment of senior management Without senior
management support, the program is unlikely to be successful. Senior management must provide
the resources necessary for the program to succeed and create a culture that supports continuous
improvement. The most critical factor in guaranteeing the success of a new audit QA program is
the commitment and support from the senior management
